talk.start.para: . - In moving -

quote.para: That this Bill be now read a second time,

speech.para: I should perhaps begin with an explanation as to its necessity. It marks a new departure in legislation in this Parliament. So far as the working out of democratic rule in this country is concerned, . we feel that we are for the first time abreast of a condition of things which requires action. If we do not take action the responsibility will rest upon those who are charged with controlling the affairs of this country.

talk.start.para: Do you mean direct action?

I mean direct action in a legislative sense, if necessary". In this country we have what is known as democratic rule, but unfortunately, at present, that rule which was fought for so long by preceding generations is in danger of being undermined. Whether we believe this authority or that authority; whether we believe with Byron when he said that " democracy is but an aristocracy of blackguards," or with Mazzini when he said that i t was " the progress of all through all under the leadership of the wisest and the best," we are satisfied that between these two opposite poles of thought we have' in Australia a democratic rule which makes i t incumbent upon every unit to see that existing conditions are maintained in their integrity. In Australia, happily, we have freedom developed to the utmost. In no other country in the world has the tree of liberty flourished and blossomed to so fine an extent as i t has here. It has grown to its present splendour of outline and state of luxuriance through not a single blow being struck for i t on this continent nor a drop of blood being shed to obtain i t . I have often felt that, like all gifts that are obtained without sacrifice, we are likely to under-estimate its value.- So we have travelled along an easy gradient down the years living under this democratic rule, perfected in. certain spots and expanded in others, until at length we in this Federal Parliament typify in ourselves and .indicate to the world that we are in reality and in essence a people governed by a majority. Having a situation like that, i t is rather a sad commentary that disorders of a kind have sprung into our industrial and commercial life which call for oppressive measures. I was hopeful that those disorders, industrial, commercial, and social, which have latterly been in evidence might be righted by some peaceful process, and before I am finished I hope to explain that i t is possible, without the interference of law, for the community, by the exercise of common sense and good judgment, to prevent the necessity for instituting a law to remedy a fancied grievance.

continue.para: When we consider what has been happening during the last few years i t is plain that there has arisen amongst us a small band of active and enthusiastic men, bent, so far as in them lies, upon the overturning of the industrial and social fabric of the country and the very freedom which they are themselves enjoying to-day. „ I have said that the influence of good sense amongst the citizens of a community is able, without the invocation of law, to stamp out manifest evils. The members of the organization to which I have been referring visited the western State and did their best to pollute the social and industrial .atmosphere there. They endeavoured to sow their poisonous seeds* in that community, but, fortunately for Aus-tralia, the advanced and enlightened thought of the people of Western' Australia never permitted those poisonous seeds to take root or germinate. Two of the men who are now serving sentences in a northern State tried their best to spread the doctrines of the organization in one of the most advanced democratic communities of Australia. What happened ? The -people of. the western State turned a deaf ear to the false pleadings of these men, and ..they left by moonlight. Where did they (go to? They came east to the big cities, those places which Thomas Jefferson has well said are the festering sores of civilization to-day. They came east to the big cities, where apparently they have been able to discover willing ears to listen to their pernicious doctrines. The result of rthe visit of these people to Western Australia, is an illustration of the way in \whach a community can rise to the occasion and make i t unnecessary for the legislative machinery to be brought into play for the suppression- of a manifest evil. The body to which I have referred is popularly known as the Industrial Workers of the World. It is an expansive title, and should, on the face of i t , make a ready appeal to democratic instincts and the finest human feelings. There is nothing to object to in the title, but the motives underlying the title and the organization and the means adopted for giving effect to those motives are such as to bring any genuine democratic community up against the organization with a determination to stamp it out of existence. It is plain that this organization has made considerable progress in1 this country. For what purpose have its members come to the Commonwealth ? To introduce and make possible a more perfect industrial and social regimes No. They came here at the close of a period when men who had grown grey in the fight which has been waged for years in Australia had achieved the freedom which the members of this organization are seeking to destroy. The leaders of the Industrial Workers of the World in Australia to-day were never heard of in this country until the battle for industrial freedom was fought and won, and now they have come here to rob us of the fruits of our victory. I know the king-pin of the organization. I know him well. What is his career? When we were battling against extraordinary odds in the western State, and also in the eastern States, this man came amongst us, but when the Boxer rebellion occurred in China he left this country and allowed t e burden, worry, and anxiety of the fight to be borne by his mates who remained. He now comes back to tell us how we should do .things in Australia, though he failed to stand to his guns as his comrades did to bring about some improvement in the social and industrial sphere. Is it not enough to try the patience of any one, that,' after men have fought up the steep slopes of adversity for the last quarter of a century and have gained recognition for unionism in this country, these mushroom and cancerous growths should appear amongst us and try to wither the beautiful tree of liberty and rob us of the fruits of. all our strivings ? Where these people have come from nobody knows and irbbody cares, but they are making us care now since the screen has been pulled aside, and we have been able to discover the true inwardness of their motives. I appeal to honorable senators, and especially to all who have trodden the thorny path in the past and by their efforts brought about the era of freedom that obtains in Australia to-day, not to deal too tenderly with the men who are now endeavouring to rob us of that freedom..

talk.start.para: Not - too tenderly? Six months seems to me to be very tender as a penalty.

It is quite true that i t is perhaps somewhat too tender. I ask honorable senators to run through the list of the leaders of this organization and ask where they were when the battle for in dustrial freedom was being fought in Australia. Like the boy who stood on the burning deck, they were not there
I have always thought he stood to his post.

Honorable senators laugh at what I have said, but that is the worst of being too impetuous. If I had been listening to myself from another part of the chamber I should have waited until the sentence was completed. I should have known then that i t was my intention to say that they were not where they were wanted. They come now where they are not wanted, and they come at a time when they may, if unchecked, bring about the ruin and destruction of all the good work that has been accomplished by those who were early in the field. I believe that the organization to which I refer had its origin in America, a country where the battle of Democracy has not yet been fought out. They have come to teach the Democracy of Australia how to fight their battle after having failed in the, country of their origin. If we need leaders and guides in any field of activity we look for men who can point to a successful career in that particular field. We do not require men Who have failed in the fight for Democracy in the country of their origin to come here to teach us to do the things that we have already done. We do not want such people to come here and menace the liberty we have gained, and who may succeed in destroying that liberty unless heed is at once taken of their action.

continue.para: Happily, in Australia we have majority rule. It is not a fetish to which I am at all times prepared to bow down, because I know that the majority may be wrong as well as right. But so far we have discovered no better expedient for arriving at the opinion of the people, and although at times i t may be harsh, inconsistent, and even vindictive in its operation, we must for the time being depend upon majority rule to enforce the principles of Democracy for lack of some better expedient. We are glad to have majority rule in Australia to-day, but these people would undermine that principle, which has meant so much in the success of our movement. There are in this community practically no leisured individuals. We are a community of breadwinners, and nothing else. We may differ as to the form which our industrial, social, and economic legislation should take, but we are determined that it shall be directed and moulded by the majority of the people's representatives in a deliberative assembly. Here we -have to deal with men who are tossing aside this principle, covenant, and guard against reaction. Perhaps there is no lesson more clearly taught by history than the fact that history has a habit of repeating itself. We have a Democracy here with everything ready to hand to mould and fashion its destiny, and we find men coming amongst us with the intention to bring that system into disrepute and undermine it. I say that i t is the duty of every friend of Democracy to set aside the individuals who would bring about such a state of Ahings. Men cannot be Democrats and at the same time sustain or have any sympathy with the Industrial Workers of the World. What are the methods of this organization ? Under the system of majority rule we have adopted a method of counting heads, but the Industrial Workers of the World prefer to break heads to accomplish their object. We test the sense of the majority as to what is best to be done. The sense of the majority of the people of Australi is reflected from time to time in our Parliaments. But the Industrial Workers of the World say that men should not be approached by national methods. They contend that the way to convince a man is to take away his life or his liberty or to rob him of his property. Nothing is more definitely established than the democratic principle that the units of a community are to be approached through the gateway of reason, but the Industrial Workers of the World do not propose to approach the individual by those means. They propose, rather, to approach him with the firestick and the firearm, the instruments of unreasoning brutality, rather than the instrument!; of reason and equity. We have in Australia the purest form of Democracy to be seen in any part of the globe. There is no equal in human history to the freedom we enjoy in Australia to-day. Having that priceless possession it is up to us to see that no influence is encouraged -which would lessen the measure of democratic freedom which our ceaseless efforts. in the past have made the established order of things in the Commonwealth to-day. When an organization like this ,proposes to supplant the reign of reason with the. reign of force, it is about time that society took some action to suppress i t , because we must not forget that society has its rights as well as the individual. Down the vista of the years a continuous battle has been waged against the encroachment on the welfare of the individual by society. But in this instance the position, is exactly reversed, and the interests and welfare of society are being encroached upon by individuals.' * If we are prepared to stand idly by and to allow that state of things to continue, we shall deserve to lose the respect which is entertained for our. democratic institutions, which hitherto we have regarded with so much pride.

The purpose of the Bill is to secure the enactment of ' legislation which will enable punishment to be administered for offences that up to date have not been recognised as offences in the eye of the law. The measure will also be used for the purpose of supplementing and strengthening existing legislation. In i t we propose to impose penalties for crimes which up to date have not found a place in our common law. In view of recent happenings, i t is obviously time that we took stock of the position; i t is time that we dealt with those individuals who have come here to rob us of our liberty, and to wrench from us the fruits gained by many years of struggle; i t is time that we toed the scratch, and, as a Parliament, determined to scotch' these social vipers.

talk.start.para: To what crimes does the Minister refer?

Clause s 4 and 5 of the Bill deal with crimes which hitherto have not been included in the category of crimes. We now find ourselves confronted with unprecedented conditions in the history of Democracy, and i t is therefore up to Democracy to assert itself. If these men are allowed to gain ground - a s they have gained i t — if they are allowed to get their members into the railway service and the fire brigade service to an alarming degree, and Parliament stands impotently by, Parliament will deservedly be brought into disrepute.

continue.para: A word or two upon the doctrine of going slow—tha t false doctrine which is preached by the Industrial Workers of the World. I am entitled to comment on this evil aspect of an evil programme which has been promulgated in this country during the past few years. With rare exceptions I have never lost an opportunity of telling my audiences in Western Australia that the man who does not do a fair day's work for a fair day's wage is an enemy of the Labour partv. as well as his own worst enemy. When men openly preach the insane policy of loafing, that circumstance 'in itself—eve n if there were no other—woul d justify the introduction of a measure of this description.

talk.start.para: This Bill does not deal with members who preach that doctrine unless they are members of an unlawful organization.

When once we declare an association like the Industrial Workers of the World an unlawful association, we pillory i t before the people, and enable them to size up whether or not i t ought further to exist in any form. When we know that one of its doctrines is that of going slow— a doctrine the practice of which would have such fatal and fateful consequences to a young country like this - i t is time that we branded its authors as enemies of the public.
The Bill does not deal with them.

f the doctrine of going slow were to find favour here to any appreciable extent, i t would be the worst thing that could happen to the mere handful of population that at present holds this continent. What is the: position ? We came here and dispossessed a native race. On what grounds? On. no other ground than that its members, were "going slow," and were not making the best use of i t
—O n the ground that we wanted i t .

We dispossessed them, and now i t is suggested that we,, in our turn, should " go slow," as the aborigines before us had been doing. If we wish to protect this continent, we cannot accomplish our purpose by " going slow." If the people once get into their heads the idea that they can adopt that policy, they will pave the way for the in coming of an invader, who will make better use of this country. I do not desire to labour the question. I am confident that the Bill, though its appearance may be rather late, will receive the whole-hearted support of every member of this Chamber. It is a measure which is calculated to stamp out the disorders of which I have spoken, to brand as unlawful an association which should never have found a footing here, and to enable us to continue the task of working out our own destiny by peaceful methods.

. - I do not pretend that I could, even if I tried, work up any enthusiasm for this Bill, in the way that the Minister for Works has done. In my opinion, it is scarcely worth the time that we are asked to devote to its consideration. In saying that, I hardly think it necessary to assume that honorable senators have as strong a loathing of the crimes which are recited in the measure as it is possible for civilized beings to have. There cart be no sympathy with such crimes. But when Senator Lynch urged that these crimes were of so serious a nature that we could not afford to deal tenderly with them, I could not refrain from interjecting that so severely do the Government propose to deal with them that under this Bill they contemplate imposing a punishment of six months' imprisonment.
And deportation as well; that is a big punishment.

We can size up the significance that is attached to the Bill by the fact that adequate punishment for the offences - t o describe which Ministers here and elsewhere have exhausted every adjective in the dictionary's evidently six months' imprisonment.
- But there is deportation as well.

If there be an attempt to make the punishment fit the crime, we can only judge of the nature of the crime by the extent of the punishment that will be inflicted under the Bill, and not by the language employed by the Minister. I cannot become deeply immersed in this measure, but there are one or two points connected with i t to which I would like to direct attention. To describe the Industrial Workers of the World organization as a widespread one is altogether a mistaken idea. The In dustrial Workers of the World is not an organization. It is a gang of criminals.
- It is also an organization.

It is a gang of criminals who practise incendiarism and murder. It is true that there are thousands of persons in this country who have unconsciously imbibed some of the Industrial Workers of the World doctrines, but they are not members of that association. The men who have been associated with acts of violence in Sydney are not members of a political organization, but are merely a band of criminals. But when we go beyond that aspect of the question, and deal with the spread of their doctrines, I believe that some of those doctrines have obtained acceptance in the minds of many of the younger generation to an extent far beyond the membership of the Industrial Workers of the World.
- Does the honorable senator know that the Industrial Workers o£ the World obtained 100,000 members in America during the first year of its existence ?

I challenge the Minister for Works to furnish the Senate with the number of members enrolled in the Industrial Workers of the World as disclosed by the books which were seized by the authorities in Sydney. The reason why I stress this point is that the Bill differentiates between an offence when i t is committed by an individual and the same offence when i t is committed by an individual who happens to be a member of an organization. Now, if a man attempts of his own volition to burn down my house, his offence is just as great as if he attempted to burn it down as a member' of an organization. Yet when we come to the less actively criminal aims of the Industrial Workers of the World a distinction is made in this B ill between the members of that organization and ordinary citizens. The Minister has referred to the doctrine of " going slow " that has been so assiduously promulgated. I agree with him that i t is the most insidious poison that can be injected into the veins of any community. A lazy, ineffective community can no more succeed in the struggle for life than can a lazy, ineffective individual. We would be false to ourselves if we refused to recognise that this pernicious doctrine has obtained disciples in Australia, and that i t is being practised' here. The only question which we have to consider now is, Has the virus been inoculated, and is i t likely to grow 1 I believe that i t has been injected into the veins of the community, and there are not wanting evidences that i t is spreading, though, there is no evidence to justify a wholesale charge against the workers of Australia. Nevertheless, there is sufficient evidence to make every thoughtful man ask himself whether, the weeds being present, i t is not time to commence pulling them up before they overrun the garden. I wish now to emphasize the distinction which the Bill draws between an individual who is a member of the Industrial Workers of the World Association and one who is not. The Bill provides that any one being a member of an unlawful association, who advocates, encourages, incites, or instigates to any action intended or calculated to prevent or hinder the production, manufacture, or transport for purposes connected with the war of troops, arms, munitions, or warlike material, including foodstuffs, shall be guilty of an offence. But any one' who commits that offence, whether he is a member of an association or not, is doing a public wrong. To show how great that wrong is as i t exists today, quite recently the newspapers of Lithgow and Sydney reported Police Court proceedings, showing that at the Lithgow Small Arms Factory a man named Quinlan was put on a certain machine, and turned out 120 of the particular article on which he was engaged per day. The union, or somebody, or custom, had established 100 as the limit, and the evidence given at the Court disclosed that Quinlan was warned, not only by his fellow workmen, but by the secretary o,f the union, that he was not to .exceed 100. He did exceed i t , and a man named Marshland assaulted him outside. The evidence was clear that he assaulted him for that very: reason, that he had refused to obey the warning given him in the factory. Marshland was- fined £ 3 8s. Quinlan was again warned, but took no notice of the warning, saying that he was going to do a fair thing. Marshland and three others waylaid him a few days afterwards, and again assaulted him. The evidence showed that Marshland incited the other men by. saying, " Go on, i t will only cost you £ 3 8s."—the amount which he had been previously fined. The men were brought before the Court, and again fined, but they are still working at the factory I It is of no use talking about I.W.W.-ism, and raising a scare that there is some hideous institution gripping our industries by the throat when the go-slow policy is actually applied to the production of munitions for the war. I shall have a great deal more faith in the sincerity of the Government's desire to. root out this embryonic, but still growing, evil if they tackle i t where they have ample control. I direct the attention of the Minister to that case. I am going on the newspaper reports of the proceedings at the Court, but it says very little for the administration of the Factory, and is indeed a reflection on the administration of the whole Department, that the occurrence was not reported to headquarters. I brought the matter under notice myself, and wires asking for reports were sent from here.
- It might not be correct.

— I am sorry to say i t is correct, and T am not speaking without authority. When the thing happened, very short action should have been taken. If the manager did not have the power, he should have brought the case under the notice of the Minister. I believe many managers of our public institutions feel that they have to put up with that sort of thing, because they hesitate to force a row with the unions. I am sure my honorable friends, who are closely associated with the unions, do not believe in that sort of thing, and they will confer the biggest and most lasting benefit on unionism if they make i t their business to denounce i t . I know what their feelings are, and that not one of them would support i t
- We have had to fight that in every union.

Ther e is a very short way of dealing with the secretary of the union at Lithgow. Of course, if the thing is showing itself in every union, i t has to be fought, but i t is of no use to say that i t is the Industrial Workers of the World organization that you are up against." We might as well look things squarely in the face. If it is merely a small growth, i t can be rooted out, by the influence of the more sober-minded men in the Labour movement, because they must see that if i t is allowed to go on i t must mean suicide for the unions.
- Seeing that these men are against the Labour party, may there not be a few of them in some of the Liberal organizations?

It is. quite possible. If Senator McKissock can bring under my notice any case where an I.W.W. man is in the Liberal ranks and is practising I.W.W. principles, I shall do what I suggest should be done by the best friends of the Labour party in this case.
- I can mention some I.W.W. men who voted for you at the last election.
The honorable senator is evidently better acquainted with them than I am, but what sort of an opinion must the Industrial Workers of the World have of him if they voted for me in preference to him?
- They, only used you to beat me.

Ther e was no compliment to me in any vote they gave me, but "we know that at all elections men give votes to some' one they do not like to block some one whom they like less. This evil is -largely under the control of the unions themselves. The evidence in this case was that the man had been warned by the union secretary. Surely the unions of this country have some control over him, or has the movement got so strong a hold on the unions, as Senator Watson suggests, that, although they are fighting it , they cannot throw i t out?
- I did not say that. T. say that unionism has a strong hold of it.

If it has, unionism should, in its own interests, throw out these seven devils. If i t does not, they are going to swallow unionism. If the evidence given at the Police Court is correct, and I have to assume that i t is until it is challenged, the responsibility rests on those who control or lead the trade union movement to see at once that that secretary is called to account for what he did. It is of no use for them to say they are against this sort of thisng, if the officials of the unions are allowed to encourage i t . It seems to me. that ,the B ill is going to be ineffective, inasmuch as i t does not deal with the evil itself unless i t is practised by those who come together as an organization. In fact, i t does not seem to matter much whether the Bill is passed or not. I am going to support i t , but I am not going to make any pretence about it. I believe that, under the common law in every State, those who endanger human life can already be dealt with. The Bill provides for summary procedure, which is an advantage. It shortens the time, but changes the method by which the criminal is tried. However, so far as the rest of the Bill is concerned, I cannot regard i t as material. It does not strike at. the real evil when i t allows individuals, as individuals, to do a thing which i t forbids to members bf an organization. They become criminals only when they join an association, and enter their names on a membership roll. The way out is so easy that I cannot regard the Bill as of much importance one way or the other." I notice that, in clause 4, the destruction of human life and the destruction of property are placed on the .same plane. It is rather strange to find that in any B ill at this time of day, more particularly coming from those who have long claimed that there should always be a sharp distinction between the values attached to life and property.
- But they are controlled now by the Cook party.

That is not the reason.- It may arise from the desire to bring the offence under the Summary Pro cedure Act, and I think, under that Act, the punishment is limited to six months, which may possibly account for the same punishment being attached to both crimes; but it is still an anomaly to put an offence against human life in the same category as an offence against property. If , however, the provision arises from a mistake on the part of the Government, they might consider whether i t is not wise even now to differentiate between the punishments allotted to those who seek to destroy human life and those who are guilty of the still serious, but comparatively minor, offence of destroying property.

.- Like the Leader of the Opposition, I have no desire to take the. Bill seriously. The Minister introducing it spoke in a strain of such deadly earnest that I really began to think, while not looking at the Bill, that the Government were in earnest. If the evils arising from the organization to which he referred are so great, surely the Government could have introduced a Bill that would have been operative over a 'longer period than " the war and six months thereafter, but no longer." If evils which are pointed to with so much enthusiasm and earnestness are such a grave menace to our existing society, why are they a menace only during the' term of the war and for six months thereafter?
Because the Government have no power except under the War Precautions Act.

I believe that under the War Precautions Act, as we passed it, the Government could have made the period of this measure longer, if they really believed what they say. Senator Lynch has assured us that he has been personally quite brave enough to meet the Industrial Workers of the World men, and .point out that the unionist who is not prepared to do a fair day's work for a fair day's pay is a traitor to his union and his organization. I do not know much about this Industrial Workers of the World business, but I am told that their argument for going slow is based upon the very proposition that Senator Lynch so bravely put before the unions. They argue, that if a man has to do a fair day's work for a fair day's pay i t is quite logical to say he should do a good day's work for a good day's pay, and the natural consequence is that • he should do a bad day's work for a bad day's pay.
- Do you mean that the Small Arms Factory is paying a bad day's wage?
I am simply stating a fact
- Do you know the constitution of the Industrial Workers of the World ?

I do not; but speaking from my personal experience, which is also that of every early member of the Labour party, I can say that at one time the Liberals branded us as criminals who were only waiting until they got power to allow the idle and unthrifty to rob the thrifty and industrious of what they had gathered together by years of hard toil. I might add that in those days, had a measure been introduced to impose certain nains and penalties upon the members of the Labour party, there were men in the Liberal organizations, including some who were not in Parliament, who would have advocated its passage, really believing that we were a criminal menace to societv.
- But the Labour party never preached those doctrines.

Our opponents continually asserted that we did preach them. People) on farms were told by Liberal organizers all sorts of tales. One farmer was assured that if the Labour party came into power at the next election they would come for his off-side leader, and when he read that the Labour party had won he spent days waiting with a double-barrelled gun for the man to ap-t pearl Those things were said against a party which never had in its ranks any one with dishonest motives in respect of the wealth of others. It is therefore quite possible that exaggerated ideas may be entertained as to the constitution of the organization known as the Industrial Workers of the World. If the Minister introducing the B ill had put the constitution of the organization in the Bill he' might have given us a better understanding of its objects. We repudiate altogether any connexion with the Industrial Workers of the World. We have repudiated i t absolutely.
- Some of the unions did not.

We repudiated i t just as a section of the Government supporters repudiated the Labour party, and now charge us with taking our instructions from outside bodies. I am going to place before the Senate the views on this subject of the Executive or Labour Conference, that body'which speaks for those outside organizations which honorable senators opposite are pleased to term are our masters, and personally I admit I am quite prepared to recognize them as our masters.
- I never . used the term.
Doe s the honorable senator seriously suggest that any senator on this side of the chamber has associated members of his party with the Industrial Workers of the World?
- Your leader did it during the referendum campaign.

h reply to the interjection I may say I believe that this Bill has been introduced for the purpose of associating our party with the Industrial Workers of the World, and if I am wrong T shall be pleased to have a contradiction from the Government.
- Absolutely no.
The honorable senator is wrong, and he does not answer my question. I want to know if he contends that we have associated his party with the Industrial Workers of the World?
- Senator Lynch said so a few minutes ago.
The resolution of the Labour Conference to which I have referred reads as follows:

quote.para: That this Conference of the Australian Labour party emphatically protests against the unscrupulous attempt made during the recent conscription campaign hy Mr. Hughes and others to associate the Labour party with the methods and the members of the Industrial Workers of the World.

continue.para: Now there is an emphatic protest by the governing body of the Labour movement in Australia against the methods of the Industrial Workers of the World.

talk.start.para: - Was that motion carried unanimously?
— Absolutely, without a dissentient voice.
- I think Senator Gardiner said something about it.
I am speaking of what I know, and I repeat that the executive of the Labour movement, representing our political masters, have declared against the Industrial Workers of the World.
- Our' alleged masters.

I do not care whether the outside organizations, are regarded as our alleged masters or not, but I do know that if I were not working for them I would probably work for a harder master. Now let us have a look at this " go-slow " movement which has been so emphatically condemned of late,- and see what it represents. Is the "go-slow" policy peculiar ;to the working classes 1
- Give a lawyer a good case, and you will soon see.

My honorable friend has given me an apt illustration. Give a lawyer fat fees, and in many cases he will time his argument by the clock, knowing quite well that the adjournment of the Court will bring a refresher tb his brief. I venture to say that even in 'this Parliament may be found some men whose arguments would at any rate bring them under the suspicion of their clients in this respect, especially as the unfortunate client knows only too well that, as a rule, he has to pay. That sort of thing is going on all the time, and i t has become the joke of the Courts, but nobody has been offended at i t . But let this principle be applied by the working men, and society is at once shocked because the idea is held- that if men are honest they will do a fair day's work for a fair day's pay, and anything that causes them to act "otherwise must be regarded as a menace to society.
- But men are no longer honest if they practise the "go-slow" policy.
Some are not honest because they work too quick.

I have instanced the barristers in illustration of my argument, and if any honorable senators are inclined to think that I am drawing upon my imagination, let them pay a visit to the Courts and see for themselves.
- The Judges have frequently brought these practices under notice.

Senator Guthrie suggested that I know nothing about the Industrial Workers of the World. Well, I am told that one of the things they advocate is the lessening of wealth and the restriction of production, with the idea of restricting the power of the wealth-owning classes of the community.
- No; their policy is to ruin employers and to abolish the wage system.

I realize that any policy that tends to the lessening of wealth injures most the men - the working men - wh o have the least wealth. There is no question about that. If the amount of wealth' to go round is reduced, the party controlling the distribution of that wealth will see that i t gets its full share, with the result that the working classes will suffer, and I want to tell the Senate that the Industrial Workers of the World is not the only organization that has sought to bring about lessened production in this country.- Will any honorable senator with any experience of the Labour movement tell me that the coal owner has not been guilty of this policy ? We all know that the coal owner has on occasions hung up the coal industry by keeping his mines closed; but that action did not shock society.
- Yes it did, and we had a Royal Commission to inquire into that matter.
And that was the end of i t

I admit that i t did shock the honorable senator who in terjected, and I do not want to forget the many years of good work he has done on behalf of the workers by trying to do what he thought was the right thing, and ' for which he is appreciated from one end of this country to the other; but I am saying that when coal owners issue an ultimatum that unless the coal miners accept their terms the mines will not open, they are just as much guilty in their intention as are the men who have done certain illegal acts in the name of an organization of more recent growth.
- Would such a coal owner be an I.W.W. man?

Yes , he could be regarded as an I.W.W. man among the owning classes, and I notice that he has not been provided for in this Bill. Evidently the Government have not reached the stage of declaring that a man who will lessen production by holding out of use, not what he produces, but what Nature put into the earth, should be treated in the same manner as a man who lessens production by going slowly, by injuring machinery, or by inciting others to restrict the output of their labour.
- If coal owners did that, would you treat them now in the same way as I.W.W. men ?

I would deal with them in a common-sense way. The Government have brought down this Bill to declare as enemies of society those people who incite to crime, or attempt, by means of an organization, to restrict production ; but, apparently, the Government do not feel called upon to deal with all sections of the community. I do not want to make any protest against the B ill , because its operation will be limited for the period of the war and for six months afterwards, and because more adequate penalties for such crimes-are already provided for under the State laws. We have an illustration of this in the recent prosecution in New South Wales, where members of the Industrial Workers of the World committed the most outrageous offences that have ever been perpetrated in Australia. Under the State Act they received a punishment which I think will remind them that there is .a law in existence in New South Wales, the punishments averaging, I think, about twelve years per man, and some of them getting fifteen years' imprisonment. I want to make i t clear that we have no sympathy for men who will endanger the lives of fellow citizens, or do acts such as have been committed of late. The man with the firestick is not only an enemy of society, but is a potential murderer of innocents. I have no sympathy for the men whose stupidity leads them to' believe that by reckless acts of lawlessness they can remedy any grievances which may exist under society as constituted to-day. I think Senator McDougall interjected a little while ago that members of the Industrial Workers of the World had voted for Senator Millen and members of the Liberal party at former elections. They did so for the reason that wherever we met members of the Industrial Workers of the World we challenged their doctrines in the hope that by so doing we would prevent them from influencing other men, and we were told on more than one occasion that they intended to vote for the Liberal party.
- They are opposed to all political control, so that is not quite a fair inference.

I can produce newspaper reports of a statement made by members of the Industrial Workers of the World, who said that, not only were they going to vote against Senator Watson and myself, but that in the House of Representatives election they would vote for Mr. Fleming in preference to Mr. Johnson. I do not say they voted for Liberal candidates because they approved of their policy, but because they thought any stick was good enough to beat the dog with.
- Who was the dog?

I think Senator McDougall and myself were the two candidates who, were to be beaten with the Liberal stick. I can instance also an occasion when the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate and I came in contact with the I.W.W. men at a meeting on the Yarra-bank on a certain Sunday afternoon. On that occasion we found the men declaiming against our then leader, Mr. Fisher, and I venture to say that only force of circumstances and the fact that we were members of the Federal Parliament prevented us from dealing out just retribution to the speakers.
And they were complaining about limitations on freedom of sj>eech, too.
- Is the honorable senator aware that one of the Yarra-bank speakers referred to tools a prominent part in the attempt to drive Mr. Hughes out of the Waterside Workers Federation ?
No, I was not aware of that
- Well, I am, and I know it. for a fact.

I am just speaking of -the facts as I see them. I want to make i t quite clear that there is not, and never has been, anything in common between members of the Industrial Workers of the World and the Labour party.
- Quite true; I admit that.
Your leader did not admit that during the referendum campaign.
e never made that accusation
es , he did, many times; and that is what caused so much bitterness.

I want now to refer to a statement made by Senator Millen regarding the personal violence suffered by a man in the Small Arms Factory. I had something to do with a strike at that establishment a little while ago, and I know that the manager has always had authority to act Without reference to the Minister, and that he will always be maintained in a position giving him sufficient power to deal drastically on his own initiative with cases of that kind. I had experience of one trouble there. The men struck because one of the men was sacked for reading an " .extraordinary " to the men • while they were at work, dealing with the declaration of war by Bulgaria. If the manager had power to do that, in such circumstances, surely he would have power to sack men for doing what Senator Millen has stated they were doing. He could have sacked the men without appealing to the Government, and he would have been supported by Parliament and the community. I would refuse to condemn a union on a renort. even in a concrete case, that the union itself would condone the conduct of an-- oP its members who were trying to put this pernicious system of "go slow " on the platform of their organization. This measure is introduced at what is virtually the last day of the session in this year. I think that I can say that we are here this morning because of the introduction of the B ill , and that the Government consider that it is urgently needed to give them the power to stamp out an evil which they know exists in the communitv. Tn the' interval of two months before we reassemble", I hope that the Government will i have used the measure, that there will be no " going slow " with its provisions, and that there will be direct action. If this Parliament is to be kept in session because of the urgency of this measure, I hope that after i t has received the Royal assent, the Government will be active in carrying its provisions into operation.
-The tact that the Bill is here will act as a deterrent.

i . ao not desire to pass a mere threatening measure. 1 do not want the Government to sit quieuy and idly, and ten us by-and-by that Lne very passing of the measure had effect. If, when the Senate reassembles I find that the Government have not used the provisions of this urgent measure, I shall then be of the opinion which I held when I rose to speak- to-day. I shall consider that the Bill was merely a sham introduced for make-believe purposes by the Government, who did not believe in its reality at all. As regards the Leader of the Government here, however, his very earnestness of language and manner convinced me, and, therefore, I do not impute any make-believe to him personally. The Bill is introduced to deal with a ' most grave evil which is threatening our very social existence, and the urgency for its enactment is such that the Parliament must be kept sitting specially to pass i t before Christmas. . If , when we reassemble there is not' some f r u i t from this make-believe tree which the Government are planting to-day, and from which they expect to gather f r u i t to-morrow, I shall be more convinced than ever that they have been merely flouting Parliament— that they have been flaunting a measure before the country, perhaps for electioneering purposes, in order to make i t appear that they are the champions who are going to wipe out of existence the Industrial Workers of the World.
- You will never plant acorns then. They would take too long to grow.

I do not want to reflect upon the Government's supporters as Senator Findley is now doing by referring to the necessity to plant pea-nuts for their use1. This measure. give3 me. as one of the representatives of the Labour party in the Senate, the opportunity of clearly repudiating in Parliament, and for the benefit of this country, any connexion with the Industrial Workers of the World. If the Government, having obtained these; extra powers, wliich they claim are necessary to cope with the organization, fail to deal with its members in a drastic manner, as its provisions will enable them to do, by the time we meet again, I shall be quite prepared to stand here and charge the Government with having passed a piece of make-believe legislation which they have not the courage to give effect to. But I hope thafc I shall not have to level that charge against them. They have got all the powers which they have asked for, undiminished, and, I might almost say, uncriticised, through one House, and, personally, I am willing to allow them to have the measure put through the Senate. If in the future there is anything to complain of in regard to this obnoxious organization, upon their shoulders, and theirs only, must rest the blame.
- Do you know any Act which has been an unqualified success in every way?

If the Government act under this B ill , i t will be a proof of their sincerity and earnestness. If , at our re-assembling, we find that in the vacation the Government have used this measure in the way they intended to do, and that is to destroy a growing evil - a n organization which incites men to the destruction of machinery, the destruction of wealth, and the destruction of property - wel l and good, for that is an evil which every one recognises.
- Do you admit that it exists ?

I admit that i t exists in very many countries, but, so far as my personal knowledge is concerned, i t exists to a very small extent in Australia. My reading teaches me that this is an 'American organization, that i t is chiefly the product of the American capitalists, who, when they are trying to beat an opponent, use the dregs of society, linked in organization, to stir up strife, to stir up anything which will prevent an opponent in a particular line of business from gaining an advantage.
- You have a wrong idea.

S o far as my reading goes,. the Industrial Workers of the World had its growth in American subsidies paid by wealthy capitalistic companies of that country to injure opposition companies in many cases.
- No.

I advise the honorable senator to consider what have been the methods of the Industrial Workers of the World in America. A great strike exists. The members of the Industrial Workers of the World may have been very active in organizing the strike. The people against whom the strike has been brought are anxious to have i t settled, and the members of the Industrial Workers of the World have been anxious to be paid as strike-breakers.
- Prove a case.
The honorable senator may say that these are not facts in America, but I say that they are.
- Mention one case.
I could mention a dozen cases. I could keep this debate going until 1 o'clock, and then bring forward whole volumes to show that my statement is perfectly true.
- Do not do that, but mention one case.

I will accept the challenge, and mention one case. In America a railway company got a franchise to construct a railway. The opposition company, which was running a railway line, undertook to stop the other company.
- Where?

The opposition company found that, by legal means, they could not stop the other company. Therefore, they went to one of the private landowners, who was quite an object of sympathy— a man who had lived his life and grown grey on his little holding—an d gave him a huge sum for his land if he would simply agree to Jiang on to i t , and even against the franchise of the Legislature and against the law, refuse to give the land up to the railway company which held the franchise. He was told that if they could only bring forces enough to protect him against the law i t would be all right. Where did the forces come from ? They were discontents and Industrial Workers of the World, who remained on the piece of land ready to shoot when the railway constructors came along to construct the line, and did shoot. I could quote the case, and bring the facts before the Senate.
- Now you say that they were discontents and Industrial Workers of the World ?

In great cities such as exist in America, where men work twelve hours a day and seven days a week, there are thousands of discontents. Let me finish the recital of the case which I was challenged to cite. These men took possession of the settler's land, and they had the sympathy of the community, because they were helping a man to retain the holding which he had occupied for years. The law was broken, the fight Continued, the works were held up, and the big railway company won. That is not a solitary instance of the methods of wealth in America.
- That is an entirely different thing. That does not connect the case with the Industrial Workers of the World.
The law-breaking, wealthy companies in America had found the Industrial Workers of the World profitable as strike-breakers or in another capacity.
- Will you connect the Industrial Workers of the World with that specific case, and give us' the name of the case?

^ 1 hope that when I make a statement in the Senate I am not to be expected to produce the proof in black and white before honorable senators will believe me. I know that Senator Keating feels keenly on this point, because I instanced a specific case of going slow in connexion with a well-known union—the case of a man who asked for another refresher; a man who continued his argument with one eye on the clock and the other eye on his client.
- Will you connect that case with the Industrial Workers of the World, and give us specific names, so that we can identify the case and check your statements?
I think that I have fairly well connected the two.
- No.

And so far as the Senate is concerned, I am quite prepared to let my reputation rest as i t is at present. My reading teaches me that the Industrial Workers of the World are there largely to break strikes, and that they receive their profits from the wealthy companies of America for strike-breaking and other evils.
- Are you prepared to say that the case you cited did not occur before 1904?

I am very sorry that my honorable friends have led me into making a long speech, as I wished to deal briefly with the B ill . I doubt whether either Senator Senior or Senator Keating is so well acquainted with Labour developments and movements in America as are most members of my audience. Let me warn them that those who talk as if the members of our unions are not acquainted with what is happening in other countries under-estimate the information, the intelligence, and the ability of trade unionists.
- The case you referred to occurred before the Industrial Workers of the World was formed.

Le t me go back to early times in Australia, when we had possibly the finest type of men whom any country was ever blessed with. I refer to the miners who were spreading themselves over the face of this country. Was it an unheard-of thing that, while one party were developing a claim to see if they were on payable ore, another party alongside that claim was going slow to save themselves work ?
- You mean shepherding.

It was going slow in every sense of the word. " Going slow" was indulged in before the Industrial Workers of the World came into existence.- Still, I do not connect " going slow" with the miners who shepherd a claim. The limitation of the production of wealth, the very destruction of wealth itself, has come from people engaged in dealing with the products of a community. A few years ago, in Sydney, you could go down to the premises of merchants and see carted away decaying potatoes, to be taken to the tip for the purpose of being destroyed, because i t paid the merchants better to hold foodstuffs for a high price than tb handle them for a low price. There was a destruction of wealth, the destruction of the food supply of the people, because men simply said t h a t . i t paid them better to handle a little and keep out of the market stuff which would reduce the price. I am not supporting that kind of thing, but showing that the destruction of wealth, wliich, morally speaking, belongs to the whole community, is not participated in only by a few men belonging to the organization known as the Industrial Workers of the World. It is a thing which the wealthy sections of the community have practised for years, but i t did not shock the consciences of the representatives of the wealthy classes, and, therefore, no legislation was brought in to deal with the practice. The members of the Labour party have been conscious of this system for years, and because we were a class-conscious body, fighting for reforms, we held together, and we still hold together. This measure is the forerunner of the legislation which will be passed when the enlightened conscience of the whole community says that, just as the members of the Industrial Workers of the World, for their practices, must be punished, so must members of the trading and commercial sections of the community be brought to justice. The men who withhold the food supply, the men who withhold the milk supply, and so destroy the infant life of the community, will yet be brought under the sections of an Act- more severe than this Bill, because there is a growing conscience of the people which says that meat shall not be held in Queensland when the rest of the people of Australia require i t at a reasonable price. It may be a distinct advantage to one State to hold its meat supply, but there is a growing feeling in the general community that national needs must be equitably distributed.
The honorable senator is going a little wide of the subject.

I thank you, sir, tor reminding me. I intended to connect my remarks,' and say that the companies who refuse to kill their beef to supply the market, unless they get the exorbitant price which they demand, should be legislated for in exactly the same way as those who restrict production. I was referring to the men who hold beef out of use when the rest of the community are hungering for it,- and have to pay twice its value to obtain i t . At present the conscience of the community does not demand that they shall be treated as criminals, but we shall not have long to wait for a sufficiently enlightened conscience to deal with these people as this Bill proposes to deal with the Industrial Workers of the" World. I have no desire to delay the passing of the Bill any longer. Though I have occupied more time than I intended to do, I hope that my remarks upon the subject have not been too lengthy. I end as I began by repudiating any connexion with the Industrial Workers of the World.

. - Honorable senators, by the remarks they have made, would give the impression that they consider that the Industrial Workers of the World is a very old association. I want to say that as an association it dates back only to the year 1905. It arose out of a combination of two large federations of labour in the eastern and western States of America. After this combination was achieved, it was felt that there was a class in the unions that it did not reach, and in January, 1905, the organization now known as the Industrial Workers of the World issued a manifesto that was distributed throughout the United States of America.It was signed by twenty-seven individuals, and it called upon the unattached industrialists to form themselves into a large union. They met in the' summer of 1905, and formed the basis of the present Industrial Workers of the World organization.. It included not only the unattached unions, but several others also. Within the organization there we're included those who believed in political action, those who believed in economic action through the political machinery, and the third group comprising those who believed only in direct action. When the balloting took place for the election of president, chairman, and executive of the organization it was found that all the officers elected were persons who disbelieved in political action, and believed only in direct action. As a result of this, the organization, which at the close of the first year numbered 100,000 members in the "United States of America, before the close of the second year had dwindled down to a mere handful of leaders. I mention the date of the establishment of the organization because I desire to show that the case referred to by Senator Gardiner was antecedent to the establishment of the Industrial Workers of the World. I wish to make it clear that I know of the case the honorable senator cited, and can show that the Industrial Workers of the World, as an organization, is of more recent origin.
It has existed in Australia for ten years.

The principles of the organization may have been discussed in Australia for a longer period, but the information I have given is taken from a work by one of the most authoritative writers on the subject of industrial unionism in America. I refer to Grote's Organized Labour in America, which was published only this year. The book has been - so recently added to our Library that it does not yet appear upon our catalogue. Whilst directing honorable senators to the sources from which information may be obtained, I may be allowed to say that there is another work published by John Fargo on Unionism and Syndicalism which contains much of the information given by Grote, but deals more fully with Syndicalism. We are, however, concerned not so much with the history of this organization as with the methods i t has adopted to give effect to its objects.
- Can the honorable senator quote the constitution of the organization ?

The constitution was given in the manifesto to which I have referred. That was the basis of the constitution. I cannot quote the constitution of the organization as it now exists, but the objective may be seen from this quotation—

quote.para: The' struggle must go on until the workers of the world, organized as a class, take possession of the earth and the machinery of production, and abolish the wage system.

continue.para: The objective of the organization is no merely to consolidate the unions in one big union, but to acquire possession of the earth itself, and all means of production and every bit of machinery necessary for production. It aims at the abolition of the wage system.

talk.start.para: - Does the honorable senator not think that the " Cattle King " of Australia has given practical effect to that objective ?

My honorable friend is welcome to his own opinion on that point. The Industrial Workers of the World do not believe in the old demand for a fair day's pay for a fair.day's work, but. in the abolition of the wage system. It acts on the principle that the workers producing all the wealth should have all the wealth,' and should adopt the most-direct means of getting all that they have produced.
- What is wrong about that?
The honorable senator may be in sympathy with them.
- Senator Senior, as a Labour man, should be in sympathy with that doctrine.

Whilst the honorable senator may believe, as I do, that the producers of wealth should own the wealth they produce, I ask him whether he is in sympathy with the methods proposed by the Industrial Workers of the World to attain that end.
- That is another thing.
Are their methods set forth in their constitution?

No , they are not set forth in the constitution, but are taught as a natural deduction from their objective. As a result of the withdrawal from the organization of the two groups to which I have referred, the third group was left alone to form the nucleus of the Industrial Workers of the World, and i t was in character revolutionary and anarchistic. The members of that group did not believe in using Parliament at all, but in direct action. They believed in going to their objective in a straight line, arid for them all means were normal that would achieve their end. They act upon the principle that the end justifies the means. That is to say, that the betterment of the workers, if i t can be accomplished by the means they advocate, justifies the adoption of those means. There are two or three methods which they consider justifiable. One is the method "of the general strike. We know that that has been considered by many persons connected with trade unions. The general strike may cover a group of unions in coordinate trades. A strike amongst the ironworkers may include a strike of coal workers and transporters of iron and coal. The general strike may involve a nation, a province, a district, or only a city.' If the method is applied to a city like Melbourne, the idea is that every organization within the boundaries of the city shall be included in the strike. The object in the adoption of this method is not so much to include all classes of workers in a strike as to inspire terror. It is a system of terrorizing in order to achieve a purpose. I might mention the case of Spokane, where a strike was declared in order to secure the right of speech. The result was that they succeeded in landing a number of persons in gaol. I think that something- like 500 persons were sent to gaol for contesting the right to speak at street corners, and th'e expenditure involved in litigation totalled about 400,000 dollars. Now, we in Australia have never objected to the right of any person to address public meetings at our street corners. Seeing that(fhe conditions which gave birth to this organization in America are so utterly dissimilar from those which obtain in Australia, i t necessarily follows that its methods ought not to be applicable to this country? Here there are three factors connected with'the Industrial Workers of the World to which I wish to direct-attention. In the first place, there is the association itself, then there is the philosophy underlying i t, which is known as Syndicalism, and, lastly, there is the spirit of Anarchism. In regard to sabotage, the doctrine of going -slow-
- What is the definition of the word "sabotage"?

The term is derived from a French word, meaning boot or shoe. In French i t means to move like one who wears wooden shoes, and who therefore moves slowly. My own conviction, is that the methods of the Industrial Workers of the World are absolutely immoral. If a man undertakes to work for a master for a given wage, he should, as an honest man, supply that which he has contracted to supply. If he is not receiving the rate of remuneration that he should get, he is justified -in adopting all lawful means to obtain i t . But where a servant in receipt of a fair wage renders i t impossible for his. master to pay him that wage, he is doing a dishonest act either by wasting the time or the goods of his employer. It is easy to see how the operation of this pernicious doctrine might have the most disastrous effects. In time of war i t might endanger our means of communication, imperil our crops, and even' cut off the means of sustenance of life itself. Besides the general strike and .sabotage, another method adopted by the Industrial Workers of the World is that which is known as " direct action." The aim of the organization is to entirely ignore political action. Deeply embedded in its constitution is a plank which affirms that i t will not ally itself with any political party. Consequently I was somewhat surprised to hear Senator Gardiner declare that certain prominent members of the Industrial Workers of the World had voted either for himself or his party
- The honorable senator is aware that there are three distinct branches of the Industrial Workers of the World here.

I know that there are two distinct branches in America - one in Detroit, and another at Chicago It is the revolutionary section of the association which has its head-quarters at Chicago, and i t is from that section that the offshoot in 'Australia is derived. The Industrial Workers of the World, I repeat believes in the subversion of all government. It does not recognise that any Government has a right to rule at all.
- As the members of that organization do not get their names upon the electoral roll, how can they have been a factor in the referendum campaign ?
The honourable senator knows that they are compelled to enroll.
- They would sooner pay the fine than enroll.

How they vote, and for whom they vote, I am not prepared to say, but I do know that a fundamental plank of their platform is a disbelief in any State action. They eliminate political parties, and hence the method which they advocate, and which is known as " direct action." All that they seek to achieve they endeavour to achieve by means of a- combination of unions in a certain direction, for the purpose of controlling, all means of .production. It is a good thing that this Bill has been introduced. But at the same time I want to dispel the idea that is apparently entertained by Senator Gardiner, that there is any intention on the part of the Government to reflect in any way upon any branch of the united Labour party.
- It is just an election kite.

I ,do not believe that i t is anything of the sort. In view of what has recently occurred, i t is obviously time that some action was taken. In the presence of such crimes as have been committed, Parliament ought not to remain silent.
- This Bill will accomplish nothing.

I do not think that there is any machinery at the present time which will reach the man who incites to crime. The measure may be a small one, "but i t will serve a useful purpose, and for my own part I am prepared to facilitate its passage.- In regard to the penalties imposed under i t , I merely wish to point out that to a man who is not an Australian, deportation will probably be a far heavier punishment than six months' imprisonment. I am prepared, as rapidly as possible consistent with due consideration being given to i t , to aid in passing the B ill .
. - I am convinced that this Bill is nothing more than a piece of bluff.

I regard the Bill as a piece of pure bluff on the part of the Government, a sham, a fraud, and a snare—particularl y a 'snare for the Labour party, but the Government will find that the Labour party are not likely to be caught in i t . There are some big principles underlying the B ill , and I am not going to be browbeaten or bluffed by the Government, nor am I going to pander to the clamour of the Conservatives, as the Government have done. I shall treat the Bill as i t appeals to me. We should treat institutions, societies, and organizations as they are and for what they are worth. Our attitude towards any given institution should be in accordance with its actions. If an institution is not guilty of anything illegal, we sliould not condemn i t . The thing to condemn is the criminal action of criminals. ' We should deal with the individual, because once you get away from the principle of treating an institution on its merits or demerits, you get on to the wrong track. If you take up the stand that, because the members of any given society commit crimes, the society itself is to be condemned, you land yourself in difficulties. Supposing a member of the Hughes party, or even of the Labour party, committed murder or robbery, would you deal with the party or the individual ? If you are fair, you would deal with the individual. You would proceed to suppress him, and not the party. Of course, if the party encouraged and abetted him, I would have no more time for i t than for him. If you are going to suppress a body, no matter what i t is, because of the acts of an individual, you may have not only to deal with an individual member of the Labour party, or the Hughes party, or a trade union, or any other institution, when he commits a wrong, but also to suppress the body to which he belongs. That is the logical consequence of the position taken up by the Minister for Works. I am against crime and criminals, and, whether the criminal is a member of a party or not, I am after him, and will deal witli him as the law demands. The Minister said a great deal about liberty this afternoon. The Bill itself strikes at the very tap-root of liberty by laying down the principle that we must suppress institutions because of the acts of individuals. I remember that in my own country some great institutions were suppressed, ' not because they were no good, but because of the irresponsible acts of irresponsible individuals. That has made me very chary about condemning or suppressing a body unless I am satisfied that i t is vicious and destructive of liberty or society. I have heard a great deal about the Industrial Workers of the World, and when the Bill was introduced I ask myself if I could vote to prohibit or suppress them. I decided that I would not be governed by the acts of individuals, and looked up the objective and constitution of the organization. Personally, I have no sympathy with the methods which the individual members of the body have adopted, and I had to go to some trouble to get a copy of their constitution. I have again and again seen members of quite a number of organizations, altogether apart from the Industrial Workers of the World, advocate and propagate' ideas that were not in keeping with the spirit of the party or organization they represented, but i t would have been a foul injustice to the movement to condemn i t because of the irresponsible utterances of individuals. I have heard that the constitution of the Industrial Workers of the World incites to murder, robbery, and various other crimes. The copy I have here is available for honorable senators to read at any time, But I miSt confess that, after reading i t carefully, I have not found a single-line in i t that .can be construed in itself into the advocacy of any of the crimes enumerated, in another place or here. I shall be no party to suppressing a body because of the acts of individuals. If I did that I might be forced later on to vote for the suppression of my own party because some individual -member of i t advocated something out of keeping with its principles. The matter is sufficiently important to place on record the objective of the Industrial Workers of the World. As I am not going to vote for the suppression of a body unless I am satisfied that it is criminal in itself, or incites to crime or interferes with the proper development of civilization or society, I want to vindicate my vote and attitude by reading that objective. I shall show by so doing that all this talk about the institution, and all this .coupling of i t with acts of individuals, is so much rubbish. It reads as follows—

quote.para: The working class and the employing class have nothing in common. There can be no peace so long as hunger and want are found among millions of working people, and the few, who make up the employing class, have all the good things of life.

continue.para: Is there anything wrong; with that? Will any one on the other side take exception to that clause?

talk.start.para: - -That is not an objective.
It is, just as the Labour party has its objective, which is the quintessence of its platform—

quote.para: Between these two classes a struggle must go on until the workers of the world organize as a class, take possession of the earth and the machinery of production, and abolish the wage system.

continue.para: The abolition of the wage system, that is all. We have at all times advocated the abolition of that system. Does Senator Senior believe, in it?

quote.para: We find that the centering of the management of industries into fewer and fewer liand.i makes the trade unions unable to cope with the ever-growing power of the employing class. The trade unions foster a state of affairs which allows* one set of workers to be pitted against another set of workers in the same industry, thereby helping to defeat one another in wage wars. Moreover, the trade unions aid the employing class to mislead the workers into the belief that the working class have interests in common with their employers.

continue.para: ,1 do not agree with that, but is there anything criminal in it? It is merely a difference of opinion as to political methods, and there is nothing in i t for which this body should be suppressed any more than some of our unions might have been suppressed years ago—

quote.para: These conditions can bo changed, and the interest of the working class upheld only by an organization formed in such a way that all its members in any one industry, or in all industries, if necessary, cease work whenever a strike or lock-out is on in any department thereof, thus making an injury to one an injury to all.

continue.para: What is wrong with " an injury to. one the concern of all?

talk.start.para: - Is not a general strike dangerous to the public safety ?

The general strike may be wrong, but i t is part of their propaganda, and you can hardly regard it. as a criminal act. If you advocate a strike at all i t is only a question of degree. The general strike simply happens to be a bigger strike than a'single strike. Of course, Senator Bakhap is against all uprisings in the interests of liberty, and for the improvement of working conditions. He would not be true to his party if he were not.

quote.para: Instead of the Conservative motto, " A fair day's wages for a fair day's work," we must inscribe on our banner thc revolutionary watchword, "Abolition of the wage system.",.

continue.para: What is wrong with that?

talk.start.para: - What are they going to put in its place?

That is a matter which the evolution of politics will determine later on. The wage system every day is growing weaker and weaker, but so long as we have i t we shall have industrial slavery. Sooner or later wagedom • will go, as serfdom and slavery went—

quote.para: It is the historic mission of thc working class to do away with capitalism. The army of production must be organized, not only for the every-day struggle with the capitalists, but also to carry on production when capitalism shall have been overthrown. By organizing industrially we are forming the structure of the new society within the shell of the old.

continue.para: I appeal to every fair-minded man to say whether that objective, as an objective, shows criminal intent. We are entitled to ascertain what is the objective of this organization, the headquarters of which are in Chicago, Illinois, where this pamphlet containing the constitution was printed. Honorable senators will see, therefore, that I am not attempting to hide anything. I maintain that we ought to judge the organization by its constitution as i t stands, and not by the acts of irresponsible individuals belonging to i t .

talk.start.para: - Does the honorable senator remember that members of such an organization murdered a lot of policemen in Chicago?
Well , does that entitle us to condemn the organization? Would the honorable senator allow us to condemn the Liberal party if one of its members committed murder?

- Members of the Liberal organization would be mutually responsible for the doctrines to which they subscribed, and they would stand condemned if the organization advocated murder to secure its ends.'
If a member of a church committed a crime, would that be any justification for the suppression of that church?
- A church does not incite to crime.
n the same reasoning, would we be justified in suppressing a union because its secretary absconded with its funds ? The whole position taken up with regard to this matter is untenable.
- Are you voting against the Bill ?

If the honorable senator who interjected would compress his remarks into a speech, he would find i t would then consist of an unintelligible jumble of remarks. He is not going to trap me. I always stand by the position I take up, and I maintain that this B ill , instead of increasing our liberties, will tend to restrict them, i t is a sham and a fraud, designed to snare a certain political party,-but, so far as I am concerned, is will not snare me. Because I believe the principle is wrong, I- intend to vote against it regardless of the cost. My main objection ' to this Bill may be summarized thus: An institution or organization must be judged by its constitution, by its ideals, and- objective, and not by the action of any individual members. I have another objection to the B ill which, -while i t does not -weigh so strongly -with me as the one I have mentioned, is still a fundamental objection, namely, that the Bill will practically mean the abolition of the right of trial by jury, which is one of the most highly-prized heritages that has been handed down to us in the long struggle for freedom. Will any honorable senator advocate the abolition of this privilege?
- That cuts no ice.
The honorable senators who support the Bill .will be caught in their own trap.
- If the honorable senator happened to be arrested for being drunk and disorderly, would he claim the right for a trial by jury?

No , because that is regarded as a venial offence, while, under this Bill, persons charged with crimes of a major character will not have the right of trial by jury. I want to make i t clear that I have no sympathy with such crimes, or with the criminals responsible for them; but I do say that every man is entitled to a fair trial. If a man incites to murder, I would not give him six months, as provided for in this Bill, but I would give him six years. I remind the Senate that, under the Acts Interpretation Act 1904, there is this •provision—

item.para: Offences against any Act which—

item.label: a
