item.para: are punishable by imprisonment, but not for a period exceeding six months; or

item.label: b
item.para: not being punishable by imprisonment, are not declared to be indictable offences,.

quote.para: shall, unless the contrary intention appears in the Act, be punishable on summary conviction.

continue.para: This Bill coincides, with. that Act, but there is no provision for an individual charged to claim the right to be tried by a jury of his peers.

talk.start.para: - Apparently, the honorable senator has an instinctive dislike of summary conviction.

I am not saying that, because I know that under certain circumstances the power of summary conviction is advisable; but why not provide an alternative in this Bill? The measure has been skilfully designed to evade this privilege to the person charged. There is not an offence mentioned in the B ill which could not be dealt with in another way, and so far as i t represents the attempt to deal adequately with the crimes enumerated, i t is so much surplusage, because, as I have already pointed out, every single crime mentioned in the measure co.uld be dealt with in some othe way. There is no necessity at all for the measure, except, as I have indicated, that the Government have in mind an attempt to scare a political party.
- Hundreds of pounds' worth of property have been destroyed and policemen shot down at their desks. Yet you say there is no need for this measure, and that it is aimed at a certain political party.

The point of my argument lies in the fact that the men aimed at in this Bill have already been punished, and some of them got as high as fifteen years' imprisonment, while under this Bill they would be punished with six months' imprisonment.
- But the offences are different. The men were sentenced for having committed certain acts, and this Bill merely aims at persons who incite to crime.
The Government had all the necessary power already, if - they wished to exercise i t , to deal with any person inciting to a crime.
- Where?
In the War Precautions Act
- There is no power under the Constitution to deal with these crimes.

If my honorable friend's contention is sound, the Government have no right, under this Bill, to go outside the Constitution. If they could do that under the War Precautions Act they could change the constitutional system of government entirely, which is a monstrous thing. In my objections to the B ill , I deny the right of the Government to condemn an organization or society so long as its objective and ideals contain nothing improper or illegal. I deny, also, the right of the Government to abolish trial by jury, and because I believe that the Government have sufficient power to deal with this matter, and to deal with, i t more effectively than is proposed in this B ill , I am not going to support any panicky legislation submitted by the Government. I shall vote against the Bill .

. - I would not have spoken upon this measure but for the vehement remarks made by Senator Mullan, and what I might regard as his almost immoral attitude with regard to this matter. He used a peculiar and superficial argument when he asked if a man who belonged to the Liberal party committed a murder, would the Liberal party be held responsible? Undoubtedly the Liberal party would not be responsible, but if we found that members of the Liberal party were continually committing crimes of a special character, that they foregathered at clubs or meeting-houses that were supposed to be occupied by members of a particular party, the Government- and the people of the country would have every right to assume that that party was a particularly dangerous .body, and should be legislated against. We have no grounds for suspicion that our friends of the Labour party, for instance, are per se going to do anything contrary to the principles of law and order upon which society is essentially based. We must remember 'that this organization of the Industrial Workers of the World has its head-quarters in Chicago, and there are very few members of the Senate who are so young as not to remember the doings of the Chicago anarchists, whose propaganda was identical with the propaganda of the Industrial Workers of the World, and who shot down policemen just as an inoffensive policeman was shot down in New South Wales. I do not know what is wrong with the people. ^ A great number of Australians, it seems to me, have a temperament which is most inimical in its manifestations to the best interests and future prospects of the nation. Is there a great outburst of public feeling; is there any great- outburst of feeling on the part of politicians even; is there any large outburst of regret because of the fate of the policeman ? Undoubtedly we regret in a sub-conscious sort of way his death, but we do not find people organizing subscriptions, nor the public declaring as an organized body their regret at the death of the man. But we find in some quarters a most pernicious intention to show sympathy to those who have actually cut off an unfortunate man * in .the prime of his life, and in the execution of his official duty. We want our moral atmosphere cleared. I have sympathy with the innocent relatives of wrong-doers. The other day I read in the Sydney Bulletin a very pathetic article descriptive of this particular trial in New South Wales, and the feelings and emotions of reasoning men were played on to a very great extent. We were told of the painful position of the wives and the children of the prisoners, and no man who is a man cannot but regret that the wives and the children of such criminals have to suffer punishment. But that applies to every wrong-doer. If we allowed our feelings to carry us away, justice would never be administered. I reserve most of my sympathy, not for the wives and the children of the wrong-doers, although I have some sympathy with them if they are innocent, as they probably are; but for the wife and the children of the unfortunate policeman who was shot down by villainous murderers while he was probably performing some official duty at his desk. That is the quarter to which I extend my sympathy. Until the people of Australia clear their heads a little, and assist in clearing the moral atmosphere we shall find a great deal of misdirected sympathy which is almost as dangerous as the overt act of crime.
Surely i t is not misdirected sympathy when i t is extended to a woman and children', whatever the husband was.
— It is not misdirected, but I reserve most of my sympathy for the man who has been murdered, not for the wife and the children of the murderer.
- Surely they are entitled to sympathy?

They are both entitled to sympathy, but there is a great misdirection of emotion in connexion with this matter. That there is a cancer, as the Minister for Works said, which must be cut out before i t grows bigger, is illustrated by the fact that the police in New South Wales, after these men had been condemned by a jury of their countrymen, had to take measures to prevent —wha t ? To prevent a rescue. Let honorable senators stir themselves, and address themselves to the very great problem which confronts them, and which will become very much greater if they do not pass legislation of this description, although it may be found partially ineffective. What are we coming to in Australia when we have petitions presented to secure the reprieve of dastardly, cowardly murderers? What are we coming to when we find sympathy exhibited for incendiaries who have been found guilty of having destroyed hundreds of thousands of pounds' worth of valuable property in one of the largest cities of which Australia is in some measure justly proud ? ' What are we coming to if there is in that city a very large volume and force of public opinion so hating law and order that it wishes to see a rescue effected of men who have just been indicted and condemned, after what undoubtedly was a fair trial? What inducement was there in the minds of the Judge and the jury to give the men other than a fair trial? Should the men have been sent to England to be tried?
- No, to Ballarat.
The men received the fairest trial which the Courts of their country could give them in the circumstances.
- It was the form of trial for which Senator Mullan, was pleading just now-trial by jury.

Quit e so. Therefore, the men were condemned by the very form of trial which is not provided for in this Bill, and which Senator Mullan so much lauded. I want to see in Australia what I call a healthy, moral sense in regard to crimes which are absolutely dangerous to the public safety. I am afraid that, notwithstanding all our laudation of our modern progress, we are substantially inferior to our ancestors of two or three centuries ago. I remember reading in one of the standard histories of England of a very much loved magistrate who, in the. seventeenth century, was found foully murdered. He had a very fine reputation. He did not occupy a very prominent position in the administration of justice in his country, but he was regarded as a good citizen, an honest man, a charitable man, and a just magistrate. He was followed "to his grave by dozens of thousands of people, who made every demonstration of grief, and who, in the intervals of exhibiting their grief; uttered imprecations against the undiscovered murderer. That is the sort of sense which I want to see developed in Australia. The people then in their hundreds of thousands showed their sympathy with the murdered magistrate. They were not reserving their sympathy for the murderer when he was to be discovered. I venture to say that with all our progress we are an inferior people to our ancestors if we transfer our sympathy from a murdered man and his relatives to the murderers and their relatives. Some years ago the guillotine had been practically abolished in that fair portion of France which is now under the heel of the German invader, and a gang of ruffians, six or seven in number, traversed the district for some months, and tortured old women in order to discover their little hoards. They murdered right and left, they committed all sorts of crimes, they were iulmTnnTi monsters. They were at length captured, and found guilty, and the people insisted upon their being guillotined. The executioner was brought along, and the long-disused guillotine was erected. The people congregated in thousands, and the recital of what took place fairly warmed my heart. My heart glowed when I read how these honest French country folk cheered as every scoundrel's head was shaved off and fell into the basket. That is the sort of thing which I want to see. I do not wish to see petitions for the reprieve of murderers and a murdered man followed by only his wife and children to the grave. If this organization, although' on the surface it may be perhaps an innocent one in the. opinion of Senator Mullan, is to be the successor of the anarchistic institution which was established in Chicago and resulted ih the deaths of six or seven policemen who were doing their duty, and the members of it, although it may be of the second generation, have been, cleared out of America, and have come here, I welcome this legislation if it will prove to be effective in ridding Australian soil of these inhuman monsters. We do not want them here. One of the main features of the Bill .is, after all, that which provides for deportation. Does Senator Mullan, or any honorable senator who may stand up for the principle of liberty—which . very often, ' under a wrong conception, is allowed to degenerate into licence—wis h to see these men remain here, and to deprive the Government of this country of the power to deport them ? I venture to say that, when he, in his cooler moments, thinks over the matter, he will rejoice that legislation which gives power to the Administration to deal with these characters has been placed on the national statute-book. He touched on one matter which I think is important. I always take up the position in the Senate, as I did in the Tasmanian Parliament, that the legal members of an Administration have placed on their shoulders the responsibility of seeing that an Act of Parliament is not ultra vires. I have a little doubt, although I am a poor layman, as to whether this Bill is strictly one. which will be upheld by the High Court. These inhuman monsters seem to have plenty of money when they 'are found guilty. They can carry cases to the High Court and to the Privy Council. They are not impecunious individuals. The state of society which they so denounce enables them to fight a case with all the paraphernalia of the law. They are able to send legal myrmidons into a Court to uphold their interests. The money comes from somewhere. This derided system of society which they are out to destroy enables them to get plenty of money to waste in this direction. They can, if convicted, carry their case to. the High Court or the Privy Council. The thing which is sought to be done by virtue of this, measure, for which I am going to vote, hoping that it will be effective, can, I think, be effected under the War Precautions Act. If this measure has vitality and legal effect only because of the existence of that Act, why is that fact not mentioned ? It does not seem to be mentioned in the Bill, and I am fearful that when it is passed, and convictions result under its provisions, this very point may be taken by keen legal gentlemen. The Commonwealth and the National Parliament will be made to look very small if we have put on the statute-book a measure which is of no effect. It is admitted, I believe, by the Prime Minister, who is the legal light of the Government, that the Bill is being passed because of the fact that we have the War Precautions Act. If that -Act alone vitalizes the measure, that fact should be stated, I think, and if it is not stated, I venture to affirm that if the Bill is constitutional in other respects, it may be declared unconstitutional by the High Court.
- Do you not think that, under the War Precautions Act, the

interjection.para: Government . could exercise any power which is granted to them in this measure?

talk.start.para: I think so; but, for all that, I am going to vote for the Bill, for, after all, we have a legal Department, and if that Department makes itself responsible for a measure of this description, it would ill-become me, -as a layman, to vote against it.' I have some little fear in this regard, and before to-day laymen of perhaps greater accomplishments than myself have pointed out in measures introduced with' the sanction of legal ' gentlemen where flaws existed, and those flaws have been declared to exist when cases have been taken before the High Court. As regards the measure itself,- I am quite sure of my moral position. People who are inclined to commit actions which are materially against the public safety, and morally against it in regard to propaganda, should be punished or prevented from exercising their nefarious intent. In another place, I happened to hear one. of the arguments of the Prime Minister in dealing with the Bill, and Senator Keating, if he were here, could, perhaps throw some light on this point. It appears that the English law is very vague. If I were to incite a single individual to commit a -murder, the existing law undoubtedly provides for my substantial punishment, but if I were to make a general incitation, I do not think that I could be prosecuted for anything more .serious than the offence of inciting to a- disturbance of the peace. I believe that this makes general what has hitherto been only particular. That, I understand, is the special virtue insisted upon by gentlemen of legal training as reposing in this measure. I hope that it will prove effective for the legitimate and. honest purposes for which it is designed, and I. intend to vote for it.

.- I shall not detain the Senate very long in dealing with this Bill. When speaking this morning Senator Millen claimed that unionists like myself should condemn, the action of certain men who assaulted the worker in the Small Arms Factory who was doing the best he could at the machine he controlled. It is in connexion with that statement that I have risen to speak on the Bill. So far as the measure itself- is concerned, it is not worth half-an-hour's bother. I do not believe that it will extinguish the organization I desire to see extinguished, which has been an opponent of mine since I have known it, and which has continuously opposed the principles of craft unionism to which I subscribe. I have no sympathy with it, and I have stated that when the members of that organization get in, it is time for me to get out. I assume that I am one of the unionists who, according to Senator Millen, should condemn the action to which he referred. I have been a unionist in Sydney for forty years, and, perhaps, have witnessed more of the progress of unionism in the States than has any other honorable member of the Senate. I know the advantages which the community has derived from the efforts pf unionists, and I am willing at all times to condemn the intimidation of any man. I should like, however, to remind Senator Millen that there is under the common law a means of obtaining justice open to the man to whom he referred. I can scarcely believe that the secretary of a union assaulted this man, because I find it difficult to believe that any man would be such a coward as to permit himself to be assaulted twice without having recourse to the law to punish , those who assaulted him. I can mention a case in point. The secretary of the Typographical Society in Sydney expelled a man from a room who had been expelled from the union. This man sued the union in the Court, and got a verdict for £500. The union appealed, but the High Court upheld the decision. I say that the man who is said to have been assaulted in the Small Arms Factory has open to him the same means of redress that was open to the man who was assaulted by the secretary of the Typographical Society. There is a remedy for action of the kind to which Senator Millen referred, if those who suffer from it care to avail themselves of that remedy. T wish to bring under the notice of the Senate the fact that under clause 5 it is clear that the Bill deals only with the members of an unlawful association. If the members of such an association disband and call themselves by another name, this Bill will not affect them. It will not, for instance, deal with the. I.W.W. man who is a member of the Wharf Labourers Union or the Seamen's Union. It deals with them only while they are members of an unlawful association. I say that it should deal with all alike who are guilty of the offences against which the measure is aimed, including those individuals who have the temerity to interfere with the distribution of foodstuffs of the country in time of war. I direct attention to another anomaly in clause 6 of the Bill, which provides that -

quote.para: Any person, not being a natural-born British subject, born in Australia, who is convicted of an. offence, under either of the last two preceding sections, shall be liable, in addition to the punishment imposed upon him for the offence, and either during or upon the expiration of his term of imprisonment, to be deported from the Commonwealth, pursuant to any order o:i the Attorney-General.

speech.para: What are the Government going to do with those, who commit these offences and who are natural-born British subjects? These men get into the unions, and are really the cause of all the trouble. I do not believe that there are more than half-a-dozen Americans in the Industrial Workers of the World here. The men who cause the trouble are British born and British subjects who are members of that organization. It is not the Australian-born members, or those who have lived in Australia for a number of years, that cause trouble, but chiefly British subjects who have been in the country for only a few years. Punishment under this Bill should be meted out to them in just the same way as to an American. I shall vote for the Bill, because it will do no harm and will do no good. What it is here for I am sure I do not know. Some of my honorable friends say that it has been introduced to trap the Labour party. But I believe that it is here because the great metropolitan journals of Australia have called upon the Government before they retired to do something to deal with the Industrial Workers of the World.. They have done something which is nothing.

talk.start.para: . - Perhaps I should not have risen to speak upon this Bill but for the fact that some honorable senators have said that although the Bill is of no use, they intend to vote for it. I have had some little experience in the Labour movement, and some which Senator McDougall has not had. I have had to deal with the migratory people who travel from one part of the globe to another. It is amongst these men that we find our difficulty. I am a trade unionist of many years, but I have been an active official of a trade union organization since 1884. I have been in every Inter-State strike with which that organization Has been concerned that has taken place so far in Australia. I have taken ah the responsibility attaching to the position I have occupied.
—Th e honorable senator has had legislation directed against him, also.

That is so. In 1890 a warrant was taken out for my arrest in the State represented by Senator Gardiner, but Providence came to my aid. on that occasion. Sir Henry Parkes, who was then Premier of New South Wales, broke his leg or his arm, and would not sign the warrant.
- There was a more recent case than that.

Ther e were two more recent cases than that, but I have always taken the responsibility of the position I have occupied. It was not for inciting to do damage that a warrant was taken out against me; i t was for adherence to the principles of trade unionism. There is not a single provision in this Bill which can have the effect of putting a man into gaol for doing any lawful trade union act.
- How can we tell that?

We can surely read the B ill . Up to 1893 we, as trade unionists, believed in direct action. We had no other remedy for the grievances from which we suffered. New South Wales had certainly prior to that passed an Arbitration Act, but i t was found to be absolutely useless, because i t provided for voluntary arbitration. But after that the trade unions of Australia, from one end of the Commonwealth to the other, demanded that Parliament should legislate to provide that industrial disputes should be settled by other means than by strikes.- Our Parliament passed arbitration laws, and I contend against anything said to the contrary that trade unionism has gained moire during the time these arbitration laws have been in force than i t ever gained by strikes. What has been the result of the disputes that have occurred? I have been at the settlement of many of them. I was congratulated by the Newcastle miners upon the settlement of the afternoon shift question. They presented a lot of other persons with medals, but they gave me their congratulations. But what has happened in almost every one of these disputes has been that these I.W.W. men have come into the union, and have put every obstacle they could in the way in order to prevent a settlement.
- Senator Senior says that they were not in existence then.
Senator McDougall knows better than that.
- The Industrial Workers of the World were not then in existence.

We have had these people coming here ever since the San Francisco boats have been running to Sydney. They have been pouring .into Sydney all the time. I can remember one incident very vividly, because in connexion with i t I had to clear out. of Sydney as quietly as I could. When the Sonoma was coming across from San Francisco some of these people, who were on board, induced the firemen to refuse to keep up steam. They allowed the steam to go down, and the vessel to drift r t . When they got to Sydney they were arrested. I met them at the police station. I told them that I would do my best to have them let down as easily as possible, and employed solicitors to take up their case. They were sent to gaol, and an agitation was got up in Sydney to secure that the ship should not leave port while those men were in gaol. However, the ship was got away. I had to cable to San Francisco asking the advice of the union there regarding their matter, and they gave me authority to get the ship away so long as union men were employed to do so. The Industrial Workers of the World were defeated in their purpose at that time,' and, because of the threats held out to me, I had to follow the example of one of the representatives of a New South Wales constituency, and get away as quietly as possible.
- You do not associate his departure with the Industrial Workers of the World?
No ; I merely say that I had to adopt the same course and get away as quietly as I could.
- Do you have any difficulty in getting them to join your union ?

Well , some come here from New South Wales, and I know that a couple of Spaniards applied to join the union, who had books from New York. They wanted to join the Seamen's Union, but we had no alliance with them. I find in a miners' magazine, published in Denver, Colorado, that one of the leading trade unionist organizers of America, writing of what has happened in the United States of America in connexion with the Industrial Workers of the World, says—

quote.para: The Industrial Workers of the World has made a record that will not bear the searchlight of investigation. In its early history the Labour movement throughout the country contributed generously towards its maintenance wherever this spurious libel on organized labour launched a campaign for " free speech " or whenever it became involved in a conflict with employers.

But the bond fide Labour-movement soon discovered that the Industrial Workers of the World was controlled and dominated by a gang of conspirators who inaugurated strikes and launched campaigns for " free speech" for no other purpose save to enable the official leeches to live in comparative ease on the proceeds that were mulcted from Labour unions whose members had not discovered the hypocrisy and treachery of the official coterie who made " strikes" and " free speech" fights the means by which they collected revenue.

continue.para: That is the statenyentof G. M. O'Neill, a well-known miners' organizer of the western American unions..

quote.para: The very Labour unions from which they gathered revenue in days of yore to carry on fake campaigns for " free speech" were branded as " scab hatcheries," and the officers of the bond fide Labour organizations became the targets for the slime of characterless reprobates, in whose vocabulary no words could be found, save the slanderous invectives and profane epithets of a " bummery,"—

continue.para: I have endeavoured to ascertain from an American slang dictionary the meaning of this term, but without success. The article continues—

quote.para: whicb, for moral rottenness, would bring the blush of shame to the lowest degenerate of the Bowery. The I.W.W. is doomed and damned, and when the last vestige of its unholy existence has dropped into a dishonoured grave, no member of organized Labour will shed a tear as a tribute to its memory.

continue.para: These words were written by a Labour man, and were published in a Labour newspaper. A succeeding article shows what Labour organization has accomplished in America—tha t i t has succeeded in carrying fifty-nine planks of its platform. I have given honorable senators the testimony of persons in America who have had much more experience of the Industrial Workers of the World than we have, and I earnestly submit that we should attach weight to their judgment. I hope that we shall always keep our unionistic ranks as pure as possible. No matter what may be my political differences with my honorable friends opposite, and notwithstanding that calumny has been directed against me on account of my recent action, nobody can accuse me, during a life's history, of ever having done anything either to retard or injure the cause of unionism, which I have so much at heart.

talk.start.para: . - Nobody, I am sure, will utter a word of complaint against the honorable senator who has just resumed his seat as a trade unionist. For many years he has been one Of a powerful Labour organization's most trusted officials. ' But he knows perfectly well that this Bill was bound to create uneasiness in unionistic circles, for the simple reason that it is not many years ago, when those who took a foremost part in endeavouring to secure an improvement in industrial conditions were accused of crimes which they never committed - crimes of which they were, nevertheless, convicted, and for which they served terms of imprisonment. I know that there is an impression abroad that, if it was possible to secure convictions of this character twenty-five years ago, it ought to be , equally possible to. obtain them under the law as it exists today. But I have been informed, as the result of inquiry, that there is no legislation which would enable a man who " advocates or encourages, or incites or instigates to, the taking or endangering of human life, or the destruction or injury of property." to be punished. I well remember - as you, sir, will - the year 1891, when there was a big industrial strike throughout the pastoral districts of Australia. On that occasion quite a number of members of the Shearers Union were arrested and charged with various crimes. Some of them were convicted,, and served terms of imprisonment. Amongst them were some of the most honorable men one could find. They were trusted throughout the entire country. As an evidence of this, I may mention that, at the time of which I speak, the union funds were exhausted, and the men were unable to purchase the necessaries of life. But, despite these facts, those who had the means of providing for their needs unhesitatingly did so. The storekeepers gave them credit to the extent of thousands of pounds by supplying them with provisions and stock; and I am proud" to say that, after the lapse of twelve or eighteen months, there was not a penny-piece owing to any of these storekeepers. This, sir, conclusively proves that they were honorable men. Their leaders were out to alter the conditions which existed, but they were not out to destroy property, although it was frequently stated that they were. I well remember information being transmitted to Brisbane to the effect that some of the shearers were shooting indiscriminately at buildings in which there were a number of people whose lives were thus endangered. This accusation, like a good many others, subsequently proved to be unfounded. News was also received that the unionists had poisoned a tank of water. The city man doubtless associated that piece of intelligence with the poisoning of a tank of water containing perhaps 1,000 gallons, but those who know the back-blocks knew that it referred to an underground tank, which would hold thousands upon thousands of gallons. When this startling bit of news came to hand, a number of us waited upon the Central Office and asked that the police should substantiate the charge by forwarding a sample df the water for analysis. That water, upon being analyzed, was found to contain enough strychnine to prove fatal to any person who drank only a wineglassful of it. But further inquiries revealed that the charge was a put-up job, because it would have taken no less than 10 tons of strychnine to have impregnated the water in the tank to the extent that the water in the bottle had been impregnated. Consequently, the accusation had been made merely for the purpose of- influencing public, opinion. What induced me to believe that there was power under the common law to deal with offences such as are mentioned in this Bill was the recent trial and conviction of certain members of the Industrials! Workers of the World in Western Australia. The charge against these men was " That they had conspired with certain persons in Broken Hill and Sydney to carry into execution an enterprise for raising discontent and disaffection, and promoting ill-will and enmity between different classes of subjects of the King." That is a charge which could be entered anywhere. These men were convicted, and sentenced to two years' imprisonment.
Was that a common law prosecution?

t was a case which was tried before a jury; and I have quoted a charge which was preferred against them. Tt was that circumstance which induced me to think that, under the existing law, there was ample means for proceeding against men who are guilty of any of the offences mentioned in this B ill . If there is not, there certainly ought to be. I speak as one who commenced his career as a public speaker with two plainclothes constables, who were shorthand writers, seated behind him, and the members of various organizations.
- The Government paid the honorable senator a lot more attention than they ever paid me.

They probably thought t h a t . I was worth it. Possibly they imagined that there was more danger to be apprehended from me. The instructions issued to these constables was that if any slip was made by a speaker, there was to be a verbatim report of the meeting upon the desk of the Home Secretary on .the following Monday morning. Although none of the men connected with those organizations ever incited any person to crime, they were able to accomplish sufficient by the use of ordinary language to insure the growth of the Labour movement with which I am associated. Senator Millen has said that he believes in trial by jury. I think that everybody else does. But I am informed that this Bill will not dispense with trial by jury—tha t i t will permit of offenders being first tried in a Court of summary jurisdiction. After that has been done, there will still be the right to appeal to another Court.
- But not to a jury.
I understand that any of the offences set out in the Bill may be dealt with by a Court of summary jurisdiction, and that the accused may afterwards appeal- to another Court.
- Only in the case of indictable offences. The honorable senator would not expect a man who had murdered somebody to be tried by a Court of summary jurisdiction.

Of course not. He would not be charged with it under this Act. He would be charged with something else altogether. In fact, i t would be an indictable offence, and he would be tried by a jury. The Bill appears to aim, not at those who are committing crime, but at those who are inciting or encouraging other people to commit crime. I understand, after inquiry, that that is the object and intention of the Bill. There is an idea in some quarters that there has been, or is, some connexion between the ordinary trade union organizations that have been established for many years, and have had a good deal to do with improving the conditions of labour in Australia, and this particular organization. All sorts of statements have appeared in the public press from men connected with this organization. I shall not quote . them, but in order to show that there has been no sort of connexion either, now or for some considerable time between the two, I shall quote the opinions expressed by men in public life who have been at the head of industrial organizations—opinion s which have been indorsed by nearly every unionist in Australia. They put the case for the organizations better than I can put i t myself. There was issued in Brisbane a placard or sticker, which is a small piece of paper with printing on i t , and gummed on the back so that i t may be stuck on doors or windows. A copy of i t was attached to the doors of a number of banks and other institutions. It read as follows: —

quote.para: "Slow down; the hours are long, the pay is small; hut take your time and buck them all. I.W.W. print."

continue.para: This was brought in July last under the notice of Mr. Theodore, the State Treasurer. He was President of the Queensland branch of the Australian Workers Union for a number of years. He had been a miner, and had worked in other occupations in North Queensland, and spoke as follows:

quote.para: His attention had been called to' the fact that small posters had been stuck up in various places of employment in the city counselling the workers to slow down. " This." he said, " is evidently part of the pernicious propaganda of the I.W.W.—the Industrial Workers of the World. The Industrial Workers of the World," he added, " is a band of irreconcilables who stand for direct action in industrial matters, and who will have, nothing to do with industrial arbitration, or any kind of legislation for the betterment of the conditions of the workers. They think the workers can get no reforms unless a war of hatred is being constantly waged between the employers and employees. Their doctrine, as applied to Australia, is downright anarchy. It is against all order and regulated systems; it is more ruinously antagonistic to industrial arbitration and the principles of unionism than the opposition of the capitalists'ever could hope to be. It is practically destructive of all the good for which the Labour movement stands. The Industrial Workers of the World - i t preaches a- doctrine that was promulgated in a country where the industrial workers are ground under the iron heel, of capitalism, where the worker has no liberty and very few rights, where he has no political representation, no arbitration, and no advanced legislation of any kind, and where, when a dispute occurs between wealthy corporations and employees, armed strike-breakers and gunmen are called out, and the places of the workers filled with blacklegs. In such a country the policy of the Industrial Workers of the World, may be justified; it'may be-the only means which the worker has to get redress. But in Australia there is not a shred noT shadow of justification for such a policy. Here the workers had full liberty'to organize in order to secure their rights. They have political representation, and not only that, but they have complete control of the political machine. Parties of their own making are in power in the Commonwealth and State Parliaments; the platforms they have drafted are being translated into Statutes, and their own ideas of industrial legislation are being carried into effect. It would be nothing short of rank lunacy for the workers to discard these advantages and adopt the illogical, unreasonable, and stupid stratagems of the Industrial Workers of the World. I believe that every person in Queensland who, in the present circumstances, incites his fellow-workers to adopt any of the phases of sabotage is an enemy of unionism, and a curse to the country, and should be treated as an industrial pariah, and not allowed into the ranks of intelligent unionism. The Labour movement has fought too long, and has suffered too much, to permit its present position to be jeopardized by irresponsible adventurers, who, I fear, are endeavouring to sow the seeds in Australia of a hurtful propaganda, wholly unnecessary and unsuited to this country, and calculated to divert industrial unionism from its true object, and to bring disruption into its ranks.

talk.start.para: - Then Mr. Theodore is not against the methods of the 'Industrial Workers of the World because they are wrong, but because they are inexpedient in Australia?

He points out that however necessary they may be in the country where these ideas were first promulgated there is no necessity for anything of the sort in a country where every one is free to organize and have a say in political affairs. In a country where no liberty i3 allowed, if you prosecute people who organize with the object of securing some form of liberty, you simply drive the organization underground, and its members will often resort to measures which in a freer country would become unnecessary. • For instance, the men known as the Dorsetshire labourers were endeavouring in 1837 to alter their conditions. At that time the wages for married men were 8s. a week. They had succeeded in raising the wages to 10s. They were arrested because of the action they had taken. It was said that they were dangerous to society for wanting to get such an enormous wage for a married man. They were convicted and sentenced to imprisonment at Botany Bay. They came out to this country, but an agitation was begun, in England, because i t was believed that the sentences were too severe. Before their time was up they Were liberated and allowed to return. This was in the early days of Methodism, and three of them were taking the pulpit on behalf of that new movement. The result has been that four years ago a monument was erected to the memory of every one of them, and some most prominent people in England journeyed from London and elsewhere to mark their respect for them when the monument was unveiled. That incident shows that, in a country where there is no possibility of obtaining reform by the ordinary methods in use in Australia, people will resort to other methods, which, to them, seem perfectly right and justifiable. It was because Mr. Theodore couched these ideas in better language than I could command that I quoted his speech.
- Have the unions taken his advice by keeping these people out? " .

How are you going to keep men out ? A man may be a member of the Industrial Workers of the World, but very few people know i t . It is easy to buy a fight, if the honorable senator is looking for one, by going to some of the prominent union officials and telling them they are members of the In dustrial Workers of the World. I have been under the impression on numerous occasions when talking to people I have known, that, on account of the manner and methods in which they expressed their opinions, they were associated with that organization, but in every case, when I inquired, the organization has been repudiated. They have said, " I have never had anything to do with i t , and do not believe in i t . " If the honorable senator goes to any of the organizations at the Trades Halls, or anywhere else, and asks the officials, I am satisfied that he will find that not one of them is a member of the organization. If a man goes to the Bricklayers Union and says he is a bricklayer, he may be able to present his indentures. If he does so, and pays his money, they never think of asking him if he is a member of the Industrial Workers of the World or anything else. They do not make inquiries as to his religion. All they want to do is to make sure, if possible, that he is a tradesman. If he is, and there is nothing known against his character, they allow him in .
- Then you do not believe in what you are putting before the Senate, and what Mr. Theodore told you to do ?

I do believe in i t ; but no organization that I know of asks men, when nominated for membership, whether they belong to the Industrial Workers of the the World or not. In my opinion, there are comparatively few members of that body in Queensland. I do not know that they have a branch there at all, but I believe there is a number of people who are influenced by the doctrines which some members of that body have preached, and who, on occasions, have subscribed money when appealed to. I shall vote for the B ill . I do not believe we shall get a great deal out of i t , but if the Government say i t is necessary to prevent people inciting others to commit crime, the best thing we can do is to give the Government the power, and see what use they will make of i t .

. - In reply to the remarks made by Senator Shannon, I want to point out that it is not so easy, in these days of trade unionism, to take exception to the political views of any particular member, and, for that reason, there is a great deal of difficulty in keeping men who subscribe to Industrial Workers of the World views out of our organizations. But certain precautions may be taken to keep the Labour movement clean, and, so far as possible, that is done. While we may admit some of these men as members, there is no reason why they should be allowed .to take a prominent part in the management of a union or exert any influence upon its policy. To-day I instanced the case of a well-known I.W.W. man, who may be heard at a Yarra bank meeting almost any Sunday. Hitherto I regarded his sentiments as so much twaddle, and until recently I never dreamed there was any force behind them. I stated, by interjection while one honorable senator was speaking, that that particular member of the Industrial Workers of the World had been prominent in endeavouring to drive "the Prime Minister out of the Waterside Workers Federation,, an organization which he had practically built up.
They appear to be getting a good hold of the unions.

Undoubtedly their influence is increasing, and when we see men of this kind getting drafted into the trade unions of the country, it behoves us to take strong measures to keep them in their places. I mention this to show the power that these individuals are exerting in our trade unions, which are legal organizations, depending upon the arbitration principle for the redress of grievances. We find these men going even further than thajt. I do not wish to mention names, but, at a time like this, we are entitled to speak plainly ; and I say that we even find men holding I.W.W. views being selected as candidates for the Federal Parliament. These are things that we have a right to look into when considering whether the Bill before the Senate is too drastic or not'. In my opinion, i t is not too drastic.
- Does the honorable senator mean to say that men who are avowedly members of the Industrial Workers of the World, are being selected as candidates for the Federal Parliament?

I know of one instance, at all events, in which the selected Labour candidate to one of the seats of the Federal Parliament was, a few short years ago, an advocate of I.W.W. principles, declaring that the right sort of trade unionism was direct action.
- Was he advocating sabotage ?
—He was advocating I.W.W.-ism, whatever that might mean
- What do you say it means ?

What does it mean? This man was advocating the principles of that organization. I am not new in this business. I have met the men before, have debated the question with them, and I know that the moment they are driven into a corner they endeavour to evade any responsibility for the position they find themselves in. I can well remember, on one occasion, going to the rendezvous of the Socialists in Melbourne, and taking as the text for an address, "Revolution or Reform." During my remarks, I took the attitude of the Labour party of Australia, which stands for reform, with arbitration as the means of securing improvements in social conditions, as against the doctrines of the members of the Industrial Workers of the World. At the close, of my address, so many of the audience were ready to debate with me that at one time I thought I would be fortunate if I got out of the hall safely. I never thought until that night that, there were so many champions of I.W.W. ism in Australia.
- I want to . know if you are prepared to believe that the Labour organization you refer to would knowingly select as a candidate a man who was an avowed destructionist, and practised sabotage ?

I cannot say what the Labour organization knows, and I am not responsible for its knowledge concerning that individual; but Senator Watson knows him, and he ought to be acquainted with his political views. Perhaps he does know them, as well as, or even better than, I do.
- You know very well that, if a selected Labour candidate is . openly and avowedly a destructionist, he would be bound to lose his nomination.

Will Senator Watson contradict what I have said ? Will he dare to tell the Senate that he does not know'that that man, a few years ago, was an active member of the Industrial Workers of the World, and preached its doctrine?
- I do know that no selected Labour candidate is a recognised member of the Industrial. Workers of the World.

What does the honorable senator mean by the man not being a " recognised " member of the Industrial Workers of the World ? I say thafc this man—whethe r he paid his contribution of membership or not I do not know—advocate d the principles of the In dustrial Workers of the World a few years ago, and Senator Watson knows that as well as I do.
- The honorable senator is trying to connect the Labour movement with sabotage.
I am doing nothing of the kind.
- That is exactly what the honorable senator is trying to do.
But for the fact that the Standing Orders prevent me I would reply t o that interjection in a most effective manner. The honorable senator is trying to wriggle over this matter.
- I am not trying to wriggle at all, but I want you to declare yourself, and you are- not prepared to do that.
Well, what is the all the trouble about?
- You know. You are trying to connect the Labour movement with the Industrial Workers of the World principles.

Again I say that the Standing Orders prevent me from replying to the honorable senator in the only effective manner. Until within the last twelve months I never dreamt that there was any real "business" behind the threats of the Industrial Workers of the WorTd, and even when Senator Lynch showed me a letter which he had received from a man who formerly belonged to the Labour movement in Western Australia, threatening the destruction of his farm, I did not think that anything serious was meant. I said so at the time, and I really believe that Senator Lynch was inclined to that view also.
- They have been blackguarding the Labour members in the Queensland Parliament for the last six or seven years.

— I am aware that members of the Labour party have been abused, but they have been so criticised by people other than members of the Industrial Workers of the World, notably at Socialistic gatherings in Melbourne, Sydney, Perth, and, I suppose, Brisbane as well. We are i accustomed to that criticism, but I am referring particularly to the threat of physical force contained in the letter sent to Senator Lynch. I can" quite conceive that, under certain circumstances, an association of this kind might be justifiable, because we must remember that morality is very much a matter of geography. A great deal depends upon what part of the world one may be living in. If , for instance, I had lived in Russia a few years ago, very probably I would have believed in the application of physical force there in order to bring about reform, because i t seems that social improvements can only be achieved by physical force in some countries, and at a certain stage in their history. But Australia is the freest Democracy on the face of God's earth, so what necessity can there be for the doctrine of force here, where all the people enjoy the franchise, and where the richest man in the community has ho more power than the poorest? In circumstances such as these, no man, surely, would incite to violence, except, perhaps, to gratify his own personal vanity. That is how I treated the Industrial Workers of the World threats until recently; but when we find that its members have gone so far as to send through the. post letters such as that addressed to Senator Lynch, I think it is time the. Parliament of Australia took measures to safeguard its citizens. The letter to which I refer was addressed thus—

quote.para: Dear Senator,

Tom Barker, of the Industrial Workers of the ' World, Sydney, has nine months' hard hanging over his head. If Barker goes up, then we will sabotage the master class all over Australia. All the Labour politicians are capitalists, consequently we will not hesitate -to sabotage the Labour politicians. If you wish to save your farm at Three Springs, see that Tom Barker is released at once. Be sure and show this note to all the other members of the Labour party. Remember your class, the capitalist class, have everything to lose; we workers have only our change. Don't forget. Release Tom Barker, or - sabotage.

continue.para: I must confess that when I read that letter I could only smile. I did not dream that there was anything but bluff behind it. In order to understand a little about what sabotage really is, or to get instruction from the apostles of that creed, I looked up a work written by a sympathetic supporter of, and believer in, the policy, a Frenchman named Emile Pouget.

talk.start.para: —D o you mean sympathetic to the Labour party, because you are trying to create the idea all the time?
That remark is utterly false when i t is applied to me.
- You tried to create it at the outset of your speech.
No
- Do you mean that the man whom you are going to quote is sympathetic to the Labour policy?
I aid not say anything p f the sort, for the simple reason that I do not know his views.
- I maybe wrong, but I understood you to say that the writer of the book was sympathetic to the views of the Labour party.

I said that he was sympathetic to the principle o sabotage, not to the Australian Labour policy. I do 'not know whether he has1 ever written on the latter question. This book waa copyrighted in 1913, and taken into our Parliamentary Library in May, 1916. Certainly, the writer does not strain his definitions. He does not put the more brutal aspect of the question. He puts i t in its mildest possible form. He is really apologizing all through this work for the tactics of those who believe in sabotage. He states the matter very concisely in the following words:

quote.para: What, then, is sabotage?—Sabotag e is:

" Any conscious and wilful act on the part of one or more workers intended to slacken and reduce the output of production in the industrial field, or to restrict trade and reduce the profits in the commercial field, in order to secure from their employers better conditions or to enforce those promised or maintain those already prevailing, When no other way of redress is open."

continue.para: If that was the policy which was being followed by the Industrial Workers of the World, I could forgive them to some extent, especially in countries where strikes and locks-out are the only methods of settling industrial disputes. I think that they are going too far for us in Australia, where we have adopted the peaceful method of arbitration; a policy of violence is quite out of place. When letters such as I have quoted 'from the newspapers are received threatening to burn down a man's farm, that is a crime which we in Australia should not tolerate for a moment. I know something about the life of the poor fellows who go ont to the margin of civilization before they can get land. When men go out there and work like galley slaves every hour of the day, live practically on the coarsest possible food which can sustain them, and reside in whatever kind of ramshackle they can erect for the time being, when they work year after year until they are able to produce a crop, under such conditions a man who would come along and burn down a crop is a great' deal more brutal, and, for my v part, I would give him less quarter, than a man who would come and shoot him straight away. A man commits a much more brutal crime in burning out an individual than he does in shooting him.

talk.start.para: - If a man does that he deserves hanging.
He does
- Not only that, but a favorable breeze would sweep the whole country side.

I think that when honorable senators are brought face to face with the actual work of these in dividuals, they will see that this measure is not a bit too strong or drastic. No one can say that i t has been brought forward too soon.
- The only fault is that it is not drastic enough.

If it is not sufficiently drastic, I am quite prepared to amend the Bill to catch creatures of that kind. They should receive no mercy, and find no place in Australian society. I feel quite sure that working men of Australia who realize the true. position have no time or sympathy for such individuals. The latter may be listened to in a good-humoured way on the Yarra-bank, or in thc Sydney Domain, when they are letting off superfluous steam, and talking nonsense. But when i t comes to a matter of real, down-right common sense, I am satisfied that neither the trade union movement, nor the working class, nor any . other class will support such things.

. - I had no intention of speaking to this measure, because I understood that it was the unanimous desire to conclude the business as soon as possible, but from the fact that Senator de Largie, the Government Whip, has taken some time to speak on the question - and he was quite within his rights - I take it that the Government are not in a great hurry.
There is plenty of time

The chief reason why I desire to say a few words is that Senator des Largie, at the outset of his remarks-^-whether he did i t wilfully and intentionally or not I do not know—sai d that a certain Labour candidate had been selected who is a member of the ' In dustrial Workers of the World.
- I did not say that he is a member of the Industrial Workers of the World. I said that he has advocated I.W.W. principles.
Well , the honorable senator said that1 a man who advocated I.W.W. principles has been selected as a candidate, I take it, for the next Federal elections.
- That is quite true.

When the honorable senator's words go forth to the public they can leave only one impression, and that is that those Labour men who are in charge of the selection of candidates for the Federal elections do not care two straws as to the class of men whom they select.
- I did not say that.

That they do not care whether they select a man who is in favour of I.W.W. methods, as they are put before us to-day. Whether the honorable senator wanted to leave that impression in the minds of the public I do not know.
- What I said is perfectly true, all the same.

Do you say i t is perfectly true that those who, to-day, control the selection of Labour candidates for the next Federal elections would knowingly select a man who is advocating, or has advocated, I.W.W. methods?
- I am not going to allow you to put words into my mouth. What I said is true.
What do you say?
Order ! This cross-examination is out of order.

I only want to get this matter cleared up. The honorable senator has made a statement which undoubtedly is calculated to do a great deal of harm to the Labour party. Whether' he made the statement wilfully with that intention I do not know. I should be sorry to think that he would, but there is the statement.
- Might not that happen without an organization knowing it?

Senator de Largie did not say that. He did not attempt, when he was questioned by interjections, to say that i t might happen without the organization knowing i t . After he was met with interjections he went on to say that some two or three years ago he was in conversation with a man who was openly advocating the principles of I.W.W.-ism.
- Quite true.

The honorable senator was asked by interjection to say what were the principles of I.W.W.-ism, because later in his speech he admitted that he himself did not know what was behind I.W.W.-ism in those times. By inference he admitted that he himself 'did not know when he was discussing the question with the man that I.W.W. principles stood for what they have evidently been standing for recently. If that is so, where comes in the fairness of trying to associate in the remotest way the Labour party with the fact that a man who three or four years ago advocated I.W.W. principles, has today been selected as a candidate. A man might have advocated I.W.W. principles three or four years ago, but those principles, as they were known to that man, might have been absolutely different from the principles which are known to us today.
- How do you know that?

I do not know i t . When one hears speeches made in this way, one cannot get away from the idea that the chief intention of the speakers is to discredit the Australian Labour party because i t has something to do with the methods or principles of the Industrial Workers of the World.
- I will not run away from what I have said.

For my part I give such statements an absolute and unqualified denial. Here i t has been said to-day, and truly said, that only a fortnight ago a body representative of the whole Labour movement of Australia unanimously entered an emphatic protest against the attempt made during the conscription campaign by Mr,- Hughes and other conscriptionists to associate the Labour-party with the methods and principles of the Industrial Workers of the World. In the face of that fact, what further denial should be required by men who want to be fair? I am going to support every line of this Bill. I can see nothing in the Bill which is likely to be detrimental to any organization or any individual member of any organization in Australia. Some honorable senators are inclined to be a little suspicious as to the way in which things are moving to-day. They fear that genuine and legitimate trade unionism in Australia may suffer under the. regulations which will be made under this measure,. with the present Government in power. I entertain no fear of that kind, because I do not think that there exists to-day in Australia any man or any body of men, or any political party who would dare to attempt to interfere with legitimate trade unionism, under the guise or protection of this Bill. Let them try i t on, and they will find out quickly that they will get an answer from the people of Australia. There can be no denying the fact that from the moment this Bill was introduced into another House the whole of the discussion was pointed in one direction. It is well worth while to read the debate from beginning to'end. Not only in the speech made by the Prime Minister, but ih the speeches made by Mr. Cook, Mr. Sinclair and others, an attempt was made to associate the Australian Labour party with the Industrial Workers of the World, as i t is known, and known in repugnance by all Australian people today by reason of its late actions, for which a number of its members were found guilty in Sydney and sentenced. Those who have done this know that ever since a few of these men blew in from the four corners of the earth and settled in the large cities of Australia, they have proved themselves to be the bitterest opponents . of the selected candidates . of Labour organizations. That is known to be a fact.
- Some of them have got into leading positions in the unions.

— In spite of this fact, we have interjections and speeches intended to associate the Australian Labour party with the Industrial Workers of the World, but these charges will all fall flat upon the ears of the fair-minded' people of Australia. Honorable senators have only to look at the leading article in the Age of to-day to see a deliberate attempt to belittle the Labour party because of certain statements made by Mr. Tudor in another place. Those statements, if carefully read, show that Mr. Tudor repudiated the methods of this organization, with the same horror as does every other member of the Labour party.
The honorable senator is not entitled to allude to the debates of another ,place. He has been doing so for some considerable time, .and I have allowed him a great deal of latitude before intervening.

I bow, sir, to your ruling, and am sorry that I transgressed. I shall not be out of order if I quote something from the leading article of the Age, which is one of the most contemptible pieces of unfair writing that ever disgraced the columns of a leading newspaper of Australia. I quote from the last paragraph of the leader—

quote.para: The attitude of the Official Labour party to the measure, as revealed by Mr. Tudor's speech, should go far towards putting that party in the place it ought to occupy in public estimation.

continue.para: The article is on the Industrial Workers of the World, and the Bill brought in by the Government to suppress i t . It goes on to say—

quote.para: Mr. Tudor frankly admits that he regards the I.W.W. as a " disease.' " I am absolutely opposed to all their methods," he declared; and he categorically asserted (he appeared to think .it necessary) that he is not in, favour ,of the " go-slow" policy, of sabotage, of, arson, or of murder. In a word,'Mr. Tudor, as Leader of the Official Labour party, invited the House to believe that neither he nor his party has any sympathy with criminals. But, although the I.W.W. is' a " disease," and despite the fact that " I am absolutely opposed to all their methods." Mr. Tudor is strongly opposed to the measure., which aspires to cure the "disease" and to eliminate the methods that he detests.

continue.para: Mr. Tudor is nothing of the kind. He said he was not opposed to the measure, though he criticised i t , as he had the right to do in common with every member of this Parliament. But this article will be read by 200,000 or 300,000 people in this Stabs, and i t deliberately brands Mr. Tudor and his party as opposed to this measure which would cure the disease. The article continues—

quote.para: Mr. Tudor objects to the Bill for two reasons. He thinks i t unnecessary; and he " feels sure the Bill will be used on trades unions as well as on the I.W.W." Mr. Cook subsequently stigmatized Mr. Tudor's second reason as an ins.nlt tn the whole body of trades unionists. Inasmuch as it implies that trades unionists generally are liable to be dealt with under the measure, Mr. Tudor's remarks do fasten a bitter and undeserved insult on the class he pretends to represent. Mr. Tudor, however, and his party are daily furnishing stronger evidence that they do not really represent trades unionism. Their allegiance is due neither to the nation nor to organized Labour as a whole. In the truest sense they represent only the small body of officials which of late has insinuated itself into control of the Labour political machine. From these officials Mr. Tudor and his followers take their orders, and their custom is to obey such orders blindly, whatever they may be.

talk.start.para: - It is worth, noting that while the honorable senator has quoted the article as misrepresenting Mr. Tudor, if he turns to the next column of the same newspaper he will find an even bigger lie told in the interests of Mr. Tudor.
I do not know to what Senator Russell refers.
- I shall mention the matter on the adjournment.

For what reason was this Bill introduced. It is claimed that i t was introduced with the worthy object to suppress crime, and to give the Government the power to deal with such associations as the Industrial Workers of the World, and root out a disease. If the necessary power does not exist under State legislation, and it is claimed in some quarters that i t does, I am still willing to make assurance doubly sure by passing this measure to give the Government the powers asked for by the Prime Minister.
- If the Bill applied to any genuine trade union, I should not be found supporting it.

A t the same time there is no getting away from the fact that certain members of this Parliament opposed to the Labour party have attempted through their powerful newspaper organs to discredit that party because members of i t have exercised their right to criticise certain details of this measure. There may be one or two who are entirely opposed to the Bill. I believe that Senator Mullan has said that he does not like it, and that one or two honorable members in another place said that they would not support i t. The fact remains that an overwhelming majority of the members of the party in both Houses of this Parliament have declared that they are not opposed to the Bill, though they have taken occasion to criticise some of its details. After the explanations that have been given, i t is impossible for any fair-minded man to any longer try to associate the Australian Labour party with such an organization as the Industrial Workers of the World. It was done in terms of opprobrium during the referendum campaign, which still rankle in the minds of Mr. Hughes' old friends, and which were the cause of much of the bitterness that was introduced into that campaign. When men read every day, in reports of speeches by Mr. Hughes and other leaders in the conscription campaign, that they were trying to associate them and their movements with the I.W.W. principles and methods, i t is not surprising that they bitterly resented i t . There could be no connexion between them. I do not profess to know the exact constitution of the Industrial Workers of the World. I can judge of i t only by what I have learned of recent proceedings, in which members of the organization have been concerned. I read every word of the evidence taken in the cases that were recently heard in Sydney, and it left in my mind the impression that the men were guilty of the acts with which they were charged, that they were leaders of the Industrial Workers of the World, and that, possibly, members of the organization, who are not so prominent, are to be found in every State in Australia. On the facts adduced in Court, upon which men were sentenced to long terms of imprisonment, I have formed my judgment of the principles and methods of the organization, and I assert that i t is on an absolutely different plane from any political organization hitherto known in* Australia. The Australian Labour party stands for progress under the law by lawful methods. The Industrial Workers of the World stand for direct action. They would win through to their ideals, not by keeping, hut by breaking, the laws of the country. We stand to win through to our ideals by keeping the laws framed by the selected representatives of the people of Australia. That is the only basis upon which a true Democracy can be safely built up. The only true basis for good laws is that they shall be framed by selected representatives of the people, and when they have been so framed, they must be faithfully kept by the people for whom they have been made. From all that I can learn, the members of the Industrial Workers of the World are absolutely opposed to these ideals. They would achieve their ends, not by keeping, but by breaking, the laws of the country, and . i t is not merely the height of absurdity, but it is a wicked 'thing, for any man or newspaper to try to put the brand of I.W.W. criminality on the brow of the Australian Labour party. Yet that is what has been attempted very many times lately. Whether that was the object in the introduction of this B ill , I neither know nor care. I shall vote for the B ill , as I have said, to make assurance doubly sure that there shall be power to deal with such organizations as the Industrial Workers of the World. I do not believe that any trade union organization in. Australia is likely to suffer from the passage of the measure, for the best of all reasons—tha t there is no body of men in the Commonwealth who dare to penalize legitimate unionism under such a measure as this

. - I shall not take up much time in replying to the debate. I wish to say that I appreciate the way in which the Bill has been received by the Senate. We have been told by some honorable senators that the measure overshoots the mark, and by others that it falls far short of the mark. It would appear, therefore, that it must about hit the bull's-eye. Senator McDougall supports the Bill because he thinks it can do neither good nor harm; whilst Senator O'Keefe has just said that he supports it because it will root out the disease.
— I was quoting from the Age when I said that it would root out the disease.
—Th e honorable senator was positive in his admission that the Bill would result in rooting out the disease.
- Nothing of the kind.

When we have such testimony from the Labour Opposition, we are justified in concluding that the Bill will meet present requirements, and provide a means to stamp out a most unwholesome development that has recently appeared in our industrial life.' I regret that some honorable senators have gone out of their way to associate the introduction of this Bill with an effort to place the Official Labour party in an unfavorable light. I may tell honorable senators that, when this Bill Was being drafted, there was no such thing in the minds of the Government as the existence of the Official Labour party. We were determined upon doing something to meet a need that did not arise yesterday. When we drafted the measure, we knew, as events have proved., that we would have the support of the Official Labour party in this Parliament. In the circumstances, of what use is i t to say, quite gratuitously, that we are engaged in an effort to place our temporary opponents in a false position? Honorable senators should be able to debate measures of this kind without imputing improper motives to the Government. I resent some of the opening remarks made by Senator. Gardiner, in which he said that the Bill was deliberately introduced to associate his party with the Industrial Workers of the World. I can only say. that he was amply replied to by his own followers. Senator McDougall in the course of his remarks declared that the Bill will do no harm, and that it will accomplish no good, "and consequently he intended to support i t . Surely i t is very singular that a harmless instrument is to be the means of placing his own party in an unfavorable light. It will be seen, therefore, that some honorable senators have been indulging in the delightful pastime of contradicting each other in regard to this B ill. Senator Mullan went out of his way to affirm that the Bill is a piece of bluff. What he meant by that I do not know. He then proceeded to say that it would practically abolish trial by jury, notwithstanding that the testimony of members of his own party is that, not only is i t a necessary, but i t is a justifiable measure. Criticisms of this kind are like microbes in a septic tank— they are mutually destructive. As far as the technical objections to the Bill are concerned, Senator Millen stated that the proposal to impose on a person who threatened life the same penalty as would be imposed upon a person who threatened property was an ill-balanced one. Viewed in a strictly rational light, I admit that i t does appear a rather inequitable proposition. But I would point out that although the maximum penalty in both cases is siix months' imprisonment there is nothing to prevent that penalty being inflicted in the case of a person who is guilty of the greater offence, and of a lesser sentence being imposed in the case of a person who is guilty of the lesser offence. It must also be remembered that this Bill deals only with an incipient form of crime, and that the person who incites another to take life, has a severer punishment awaiting him after the crime has been committed. The measure does not deal with the committal of any crime. To my mind i t fills a present-day want. I understood Senator Mullan to say that the law as i t stands is quite sufficient to cope with the evils that have arisen in connexion with the Industrial Workers of the World. I am not a lawyer, but the best legal authorities have assured us that i t is not sufficient.
No t under the War Precautions Act?

No . The best advice that we have is that this measure will not only strengthen the existing law, but will, to a large extent, supplement i t . I shall now direct attention to a statement made by Mr. Groom in the public press. Speaking of this Bill he said—

quote.para: It was uot a new law, as it was now the basis of society. The Bill carried the law further than it existed in the various States. When persons who, in their propaganda work, incited people to destroy life or property, they should be liable to punishment. The State laws did not deal with this aspect of the case, which the Prime Minister had found i t necessary to provide for. It had been abundantly shown t>y the Prime Minister that day that there was ample justification for the Bill. There was no law in the Commonwealth that provided punishment for the incitation to the destruction of life or property.

continue.para: That opinion, reinforcing the legal opinion which is already in possession of the Commonwealth, evidences that the Bill is necessary to supplement the law as i t stands to-day. In conclusion, I feel that the presence of the measure on the statute-book will have a salutary effect. The men who have run their wild and giddy course in Australia will, by reason of the fact that society has proclaimed its determination not to be trodden upon, know that unless they reform their ways, only the criminal dock awaits them. I am pleased that honorable senators have received the Bill so well. I do not anticipate that there will be any unnecessary delay in passing i t , and I do hope that those misguided persons with whom i t is specially intended to deal, will so remodel their conduct as to become entitled to be members of a free Democracy, instead of being wreckers of i t .

quote.para: This Act shall continue in force for the duration of the present war, and a period of six months thereafter, but no longer.

talk.start.para: . - Seeing that this measure is intended to suppress crime, I should like to know why it is to be limited to the period of the war, and six months thereafter?

.- This Bill has its origin in the defence powers of the Commonwealth, and, as the honorable senator will observe, it is mainly intended to deal with offences which are likely to be committed during the currency of the war. We believe that on the termination of the war the necessity for such a Bill will largely disappear.

debate.para: Whoever, being a member of an unlawful association, advocates or encourages, or incites or instigates to, any action intended or calculated to prevent or hinder the production, manufacture, or transport, for purposes connected with the war, of troops, arms, munitions, or warlike- material, including foodstuffs, shall be guilty of an offence.......

talk.start.para: . - I wish to know whether the inciting to, or encouragement of, the acts set out in this clause will be limited strictly to members of an unlawful association.

. - The clause in its literal sense applies only to members of unlawful associations. The presumption is that only such persons will be guilty of these crimes, and if there are men guilty of them who do not belong to such associations, they can be dealt with under the ordinary law.

. - The very fact that a person who is a member of an unlawful association is directly indicated as being liable to six months' imprisonment if guilty of any of these acts conveys the idea that any person' who is not a member of an association is not liable to imprisonment if he does any of those acts, and cannot be prosecuted under the scope of this Bill.
Because this is an unlawful associations B ill

The point deserves the serious consideration of the Government, because there has apparently been a serious omission by them. Senator Guthrie's argument may be an excellent reason for enlarging the scope of the Bill, but i t is not a good reason for leaving it as i t is. The Government could just as easily have got a comprehensive measure through Parliament that would have saved them the trouble of issuing war precautions regulations to deal with these things, as a Bill to deal with one particular association. It is quite possible that in the hasty drafting of the measure the wider aspect of the matter escaped observation.
