The clause cannot be read in conjunction with clause 4, because that deals with a different question. Why an act should be a crime or misdemeanour when committed by a man belonging to an unlawful association and not when committed by a man who does not belong to an unlawful association, I am quite unable to understand. The Minister did not make the point much clearer when he replied to Senator Mullan.

. - The Bill is quite comprehensive enough in its scope, and will pretty well meet the case as I see it. At the same time, if honorable senators opposite feel that it is not sufficiently comprehensive, and that individual criminals may escape, I am prepared to help them to draw the net even closer.
—Wh y not let us introduce our own Bill instead of patching up yours ?

I recommend to the honorable senator the motto, " Do it now." If we let this opportunity of amending the B ill pass, we may not get another for some considerable time. Al l that is necessary is to strike out the word " unlawful." In Australia most men belong to one association or another, and very few would escape the provisions of the clause. If Senator Gardiner or Senator Mullan desires the help of the Government to bring about that amendment I think I can promise i t to them.
. - The. point raised by Senator Mullan is very strong, sound, and valid. Clause 4, which we have just passed, reads -

quote.para: Whoever advocates or encourages, or incites or instigates to the taking or endangering of human life, or the destruction or injuring of property shall be guilty of an offence.

speech.para: We might well bring clause 5 into conformity with clause 4 by striking out the words, " being a member of an unlawful association." It would then read -

quote.para: Whoever advocates or encourages, or incites or instigates to any action intended or calculated to prevent or hinder the production, manufacture, or transport for purposes connected with the war, of troops, arms, munitions, or warlike material, including foodstuffs, shall be guilty of an offence.

speech.para: If Senator Mullan moves that amendment I will support him.

talk.start.para: I have not the slightest intention of doing so. I do not want to make the B ill worse than i t is. I was simply looking for information.
Then I am prepared to move i t myself.
- Many a man may say a thing in a moment of excitement for which he ought not to be put in gaol. This clause deals with an association deliberately organized for a purpose.

- If the two clauses are compared it will be found that I am right. There are men in this community who have done the things indicated in clause 5, and belong to no organization. They should come under this Bill just the same as if they were members of an organization banded together for the purpose of doing damage to the Empire.
Would you put every man who struck in the coal mines the other' day in gaol for six months?
I am not speaking about that matter at all.
- You are going the right way to do it the next time.
I would throw the responsibility on the individual.
- Under clause 4 you cannot tell a man to go and kill a German.
That is so. Under clause 4, as i t stands, you could not -advocate conscription, but we passed that clause without a word.
How would recruiting go under that clause ?

.—It might be argued that i t applies to the taking of human life inside the realm only, but the decision of the five Judges of the Appeal Court in Great Britain in the Casement case shows that that argument does not apply.-.
- You would then bring in a member of any association, unlawful or not, who dared to do any of the things mentioned in clause 5 ?
Any individual in the community who is guilty of any of the offences in clause 5 should be punished, whether he belongs to the Industrial Workers of the World or not.
You are not really in favour of that?

I am. If not, the clause is only waste paper. Why should these things become an offence because a person who does them belongs or does nob belong to a particular association ? Do honorable senators realize the gravity of what is in the clause? Why should a man, prosecuted under clause 5, be able to say, " I do. not belong to an unlawful association. My friend standing side by side with me in the dock does. He may be found guilty, but I must be acquitted, although the evidence against both of us is identical."
- But there is a liability to prosecute in any case ?
No : hence the reason for this Bili.
- Failing this Bill, does the honorable senator contend that nobody who commits an offence would escape punishment?

Ther e is no present provision so far as the common law or the Statute law is concerned, but there may be some provision in the regulations under the War Precautions Act. As far as other matters are concerned, we will have to fall back upon the ancient Statute law, which is now regarded as the common law.
- And the honorable senator contends that, to make this Bill operative, certain words ought to be eliminated.
The note is in clause 4, which throws the obligation on the individual. I beg to move—

quote.para: That the words " being a member of an unlawful association" be left out.

continue.para: I hope the Minister will see his way clear to accept the amendment.

talk.start.para: .- I follow Senator Mullan in desiring to get an expression of opinion from the Government with regard to this clause, because if we pass it as it stands, it may be argued, after Parliament is closed, that the Government, by a regulation, may bring in all those organizations and unions which are now left out of the Bill The Government might then be able to say that it was the intention of Parliament, under this clause, to include them. Senator Mullan and I want to know if this is in the minds of the Government, and whether they propose to make this clause, by regulation, do what perhaps they lack the courage to ask Parliament to sanction. I am en couraged in this view by an offer made by Senator do Largie - the " off-sider " to the Government - who invited me to move an amendment. If he can guarantee that the Government will accept the amendment, I will be prepared to draft it, but I do not propose to harass the Government by drafting amendments which may be unacceptable to them. I am glad Senator Keating has moved his amendment, because, when the vote is taken on it, we shall be able to indicate to the Government that we do not want any regulations of that kind framed during the time that Parliament is not sitting.
That is all provided for

But I desire to make assurance doubly sure, and I want a chance t o vote against the amendment, which would make a body of men striking against auy legitimate grievance liable under this Bill. It ' is well, therefore, that Senator Mullan brought the matter forward for discussion, and that we shall now have an opportunity of voting against an amendment which would place in the hands of the Government a weapon which I do not think should be at the disposal of any Administration, namely, to summarily send any person to gaol for six months for doing what, under other conditions, he could do without being interfered with. I can quite understand the attitude of honorable senators who want to have things dealt with in a summary way; and if the offer made by Senator de Largie is still open I will accept i t , and draft an amendment; but I realize that the Government have to take the responsibility for the draftsmanship of this Bill, and I particularly want them to have the measure in exactly the way in which i t has been introduced, so that when we meet again, after two months, they will be able to tell us what are the fruits of the measure.

. - I wish to point out to Senator Gardiner that while there is certainly power under the War Precautions Act to issue regulations, any regulations framed under this Bill will be of the same kind and nature as regulations issued ordinarily under any other Bill that passes this Chamber. I would, therefore, suggest that the honorable senator might very fittingly leave well alone. This is a measure to deal with unlawful associations, and members thereof. That is the objective, and I think the amendment moved by Senator Keating will seriously affect its purpose. The presumption is that all the offences intended to be dealt with by the Bill are hatched and conceived in a particular way, and, having discovered their source, we propose to reach them in this Bill, so that there will be little need to deal with persons outside of an organization. I appeal to honorable senators that the Bill clearly accomplishes the work it set out to do, and I hope the amendment will not be carried, because we do not know where it will land us. In clause 5 we reach the objective of- the Bill, namely, the members of unlawful associations.

. - It appears to me that if the amendment moved by Senator Keating is agreed to, it will unduly widen the scope of the Bill, and make it a very comprehensive measure, for it will then not only deal with unlawful associations, but will give to the Government power which I, for one, am not prepared to give them in any circumstances whatever. The Government will then have unlimited power to make regulations.
This Bill is not confined to unlawful associations.
It is styled " A Bill for an Act relating to unlawful associations and members thereof.",
- " And certain of'. Do not forget that.

Under this clause, it will be competent, if I read i t aright, to proceed immediately against the officials of any organization if they took any steps, directly or indirectly, to hinder the production, manufacture, or transport of material required for purposes in connexion with the war. At the present time, the scope of the Bill is quite wide enough, considered in conjunction with the innumerable regulations the Government may put into operation under the Crimes Act, the War Precautions Act, and a number of other Acts of a similar character.

- On a point of order, I direct attention to the fact that we are discussing clause 5, in which Senator Keating has moved an amendment, deleting certain words.' I want to know whether that amendment is in order, because, if accepted by the Committee, it will destroy the whole purview of the Bill..

interjection.para: The intention of the Bill is, as the Minister said, to deal with unlawful associations.

talk.start.para: Largely ; but also " certain offences."
- I contend that if the amendment is held to be in order, the Committee will be assuming to itself the power to debate a question which really is not submitted in the measure.

I was really surprised to hear Senator Needham submitting the grounds on which he raised the point of order. It simply means that the Senate cannot delete from a clause certain words. If there were no other clause in the Bill but clause 5, and that clause were numbered clause 3, I would still submit that i t would be in order to move the deletion of any words. We have just passed clause 4, which provides that " whoever " advocates or encourages certain things shall be guilty of an offence, with a penalty assigned. Clause 5 provides that " whoever, being a member of an unlawful association," advocates or encourages certain things is guilty of an offence, with a penalty assigned. I have moved for the deletion from clause 5 of the words " being a member of an unlawf u l association," which, if omitted, would bring the clause in drafting conformity with clause 4. This is a B ill for an Act relating to unlawful associations and members thereof "and certain offences." Al l that I am asking is that clause 5 shall provide what is an offence, not merely on the part of members of an unlawful association, hut on the part of anybody. The preamble of the B ill reads—

quote.para: Whereas an association known as the Industrial Workers of the World and members thereof have been concerned in advocating and inciting to the commission of divers crimes and offences:
And whereas i t is expedient, for the effective prosecution of the present war, that laws shall be enacted for the suppression of such practices :
Be i t therefore enacted by the King's Most Excellent Majesty, the Senate, and the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia, as follows:—

interjection.para: How Senator Needham, who has occupied the chair with credit, distinction, and impartiality so frequently, could come to the conclusion that, in moving the amendment, I have gone beyond what would be called the order of leave elsewhere, I cannot understand.

talk.start.para: - I only asked for a ruling on the point.

I am sure that, on further reflection, the honorable senator will realize that the omission of these words would not mean that we had altered the scope, the purpose, or the purport of the BilL I think that the point of order has been taken by the honorable senator, if I may say so, without a full consideration of the whole position.

May I , sir, reply now to Senator Keating, who is a very eminent and able lawyer? He has said that, because the words "certain offences" are mentioned in the preamble, the Committee will be justified in discussing his amendment. I contend that those words are used in relation to " unlawful associations and members thereof."
How do you account for clause 4?

— I am not bothering about clause 4. Because the .words "certain offences" appear in the preamble, the honorable senator thinks that the Bill should give a latitude to the Government to prosecute all and sundry, whereas the purview of the Bill is " unlawful associations and members thereof and certain offences." I contend that the "certain offences " are in connexion with members of an unlawful association under the measure.

I hope, sir, that, in dealing with the point of order, you will take into consideration the fact that, in allowing the second reading of the. measure to go on the voices, we thereby, to an extent, consented to its principles. If an amendment of this character is accepted by the Chair i t will simply mean that the measure, whose principles we agreed to, was not a measure to deal with certain unlawful associations. The amendment, however, would turn it into a measure not only to deal with unlawful associations, but also to deal with lawful associations in a drastic- manner, which, if suggested at the second reading, we would not have agreed to do. The amendment, I submit, opens up new ground. I truly believed that the Bill which we were asked to read a second time related to "unlawful associations and members thereof and certain offences," which offences, I understood, were connected with an unlawful association. If the amendment is upheld, the scope of the Bill will be held to cover, not only unlawful associations, but also lawful associations. I think that this country has sufficient power to punish any person who commits an unlawful act. I do not consider that the scope of the Bill can be altered in Committee.

- Clause 4 deals only with those persons who incite or instigate to the taking or endangering of human life or the destruction or injury of property; whereas clause 5 is of an entirely different character, and is confined exclusively to a member of an unlawful association, and to that only. The mere fact that a punishment is provided in clause 4 for individuals who endanger human life or instigate the destruction of property does not imply that the power given under clause 5 can, with impunity, be exercised in that way. I think that if the amendment is held to be in order, and is carried, the whole Bill will be reviewed at once, and will receive no support from this side of the Chamber.

When Senator Gardiner stated just now that, in passing th second reading on the voices, honorable senators were under the impression that this was a Bill to deal with unlawful associations, probably he was right. But I submit, sir, that, in considering the point of order, you will take into account, not what he and his friends thought they were passing, but what they did pass. What we passed at the second-reading stage is set out very clearly in the preamble. After the recital of certain facts, which do not necessarily imply the purpose of the measure in stating those facts, the purpose is set out in the second paragraph of the preamble—

quote.para: And whereas it is expedient, for the effective prosecution of the present war, that laws shall be enacted for the suppression of such practices.

interjection.para: That is, the practices against which the Bill is to legislate.

talk.start.para: That is the practice of the "divers crimes and offences" referred to in the first paragraph of the preamble. You cannot read one paragraph without the other.

Firs t the preamble sets out that there is an association known as the Industrial Workers of the. World, - and that the members thereof have been concerned in advocating and inciting to the commission of divers crimes and offences. That is a mere recital of facts. But the second paragraph which I read is a declaration of the purpose of the measure.
- That is, the practices of the members of the Industrial Workers of the World. It is quite clear that you cannot read into the second paragraph anything which is not there.

My honorable friend is trying to read into the paragraph, after the word " practices," the words " of the associations," but those words are not there. Confirming my reading that the purpose of the B ill is to suppress certain practices, I submit that we are entitled to take into account clause 4, where it was not limited to the members of any association. These two things, taken together, do, I submit, bring the amendment entirely within the scope and purpose of the B ill .

- At the first blush, I was inclined to think ' that Senator Needham was wrong; but, on consideration, I think that the point he took is right. This measure, from beginning to end, is " a Bill relating to unlawful associations and members thereof, and certain offences." The question is: What is the meaning of the words " certain offences " in the title, and what relation do those words bear to the preceding words "relating to unlawful associations and members thereof " ? The more I read the Bill, the more do I feel inclined to believe that the words " certain offences " are intended to be certain offences committed by . unlawful associations and members thereof. Senator Millen has submitted that, if that is so, we did wrong in passing clause 4 as it stood. I think that we did. I believe that, in order to make the Bill sensible, it will be incumbent upon the Government to recommit clause 4, for the purpose of inserting after the word " Whoever " the words "'being a member of an unlawful association," that is, the same words as follow the word " Whoever " in clause 5. As the measure stands now, it is very lop-sided. I cannot get away from the impression that the Bill is intended to apply to unlawful associations and the members thereof, and that the offences referred to are those committed by unlawful associations and the members thereof. I hope that you will rule that Senator Needham's point of order must be upheld.
In reply to what has been said by Senator Millen, I should like to say that when he quoted from the preamble the Words—

quote.para: And whereas it is expedient, for the effective prosecution of the present war, that laws shall be enacted for the suppression of such practices,

interjection.para: he should, in order that the matter he quoted might be understood, have prefaced i t by quoting the preceding words—

quote.para: - Whereas an Association known as the Industrial Workers of the World, and members thereof, have been concerned in advocating and inciting to the committal of divers crimes and offences.

talk.start.para: - The honorable senator had only to read the first clause, which is the short title of the Bill.
That is1 so. The first clause reads—

quote.para: This Act may be cited as the Unlawful Associations Act 1916

talk.start.para: - The title is nothing.

I should like the Minister for Works to inform the Committee of the intention of the Government in introducing the B ill . Is i t intended that the B ill shall apply only to unlawful associations, or to every citizen of the Commonwealth who may be guilty of a breach of the law. If the latter is the intention., there are already in existence Commonwealth and State laws to deal with these offences. I do not wish i t to be understood for a moment that I desire to protect any one who encourages, incites to, or instigates the offences covered by the Bill. I have shown that - I am in favour of the B ill as i t stands. If i t is the intention that the B ill shall apply to every citizen of the Commonwealth, and under existing legislation there is not sufficient power to deal with these offences, I am prepared to give the Government the necessary powers. However, I am of the opinion that the B ill is intended to apply only to unlawful associations and the members thereof, and that therefore my point of order must be sustained.

- Senator Needham, in seeking to have Senator Keating's amendment set aside as out of order, raises the question of the scope and purpose of the Bill. The subject-matter of the Bill is very clearly set out in the title. It is -

quote.para: A Bill for an Act relating to unlawful associations and members thereof and certain offences.

interjection.para: I have said a few times that the main object of the Bill is to deal with unlawful associations and the acts of the members of such associations. But if . we were to circumscribe the scope of the Bill to that main object alone, much of the measure would have to go by the board. For instance, clause 4 would have to go, and clauses 6 and 7 would also have to go.

talk.start.para: Clauses 6 and 7 will have to go if the point of order is upheld
- The complete measure would be emasculated if it were agreed that its scope was confined within the narrow lines suggested by Senator Needham.
- If the Bill applies to lawful associations the whole measure will have to go.

I have already said that the main purpose of the Bill is to apply to unlawful associations and the members thereof, but i t is not intended that i t should have no other purpose. I remind Senator Needham that he has already agreed to clause 4 without demur. I believe that Senator Keating's amendment is perfectly in order, but the wisdom of pressing i t is quite another matter. I think the good sense of the Committee will prevail upon the honorable senator not to do so. I hope that honorable senators will take note of the fact that a desire has been generally expressed to finish the work to-night, though we may have to sit rather late to do so.

I am going to rule on the point of order taken by Senator Needham in accordance with a precedent already set by the Senate in a ruling by a previous President, Senator Sir Richard Baker, to the following effect:-—

quote.para: Amendments in Committee must be relevant to the subject-matter of the Bill as read a second time. The question to be considered is whether the amendment is relevant to the subject- matter of the Bill. If so, i t can be moved, whether it contains a new principle or not. The test is not the title or the scope or object of the Bill., The standing order is clear, and says—
'Any amendment may be moved to any part of a Bill, provided the same be relevant to the subject-matter of the Bill, and be otherwise in conformity with the rules and orders of the Senate.
And standing order 206 says—

If any amendment shall have been made in the Bill not coming within the original title, such title shall be amended, and a question put, " That this be the title of the Bill," and the amendment thereof shall be specially reported to the Senate.

continue.para: I rule therefore that Senator Keating's amendment is perfectly in order.

talk.start.para: -S o much has been said during the discussion of the point of order that I do not purpose to continue my remarks any further than to say that I am not prepared to support the amendment. I shall prevent, so far as I can, any legislation which will give the Government power to issue regulations which, though in conformity with, the Act, might be put into operation against the members of perfectly lawful associations.

. - If the amendment is pressed I propose to vote against it. I want to say that it is an entirely logical amendment, and I can find no fault with it on that ground. It seems to me that it is an unanswerable argument that if it is a wrong thing for John Smith, who happens to be a member of the Industrial Workers of the World, or some other unlawful association, in time of war, to incite men to delay the loading of a transport, for instance, it cannot be a right thing- for William Brown, who does not happen to be a member of the Industrial Workers of the World,' but is a member of some other organization, to do the same thing. . If we have to take a vote upon the amendment, and it is carried, any union deciding to strike, for instance, would, I presume, have a meeting of its members, at which a motion to strike would probably be made, and then the man who moved the motion would be liable under this Bill. I am not saying that some steps will not yet have to be taken to prevent strikes which affect our warlike operations. But we cannot deal with such a matter as that piecemeal, or in this Bill. We have legislation in some of the States, and I think also in the Commonwealth, which makes a strike illegal, but it has so far been honoured more in . the breach than in the observance, and nothing very dreadful has happened. To-day we have to recognise the fact that no matter what law may appear upon our statute-books, the strike is the accepted practice of the. unions. I do not propose that we should deal with this very big matter in this piecemeal fashion. The whole standing, privileges, and rights of unions must be passed in review before we can accept a proposition to deny that which the community tolerates as a practice, and which the law has so far tolerated. In the circumstances, although I agree with its logic, I am unable to support the amendment submitted by Senator Keating,

talk.start.para: -In moving -

quote.para: That this Bill be now read a second time,

speech.para: I desire to say that what the measure proposes to accomplish has already been accomplished in other parts of the world, and with great advantage. Briefly stated, the object of the Bill is to utilize as much as possible the daylight which God gives us. Under the existing system we are accustomed to measure time by the clock— a merely mechanical contrivance. We rise in the morning by i t , and we regulate our'ordinary daily routine by i t . This Bill is intended to set aside the clock, and to allow the sun to take its place. It is quite true that there are many callings in this country to which the measure will not apply. I know some in which i t is not a question of saving daylight, but of saving darkness, as the people engaged in those avocations, in order to earn a livelihood, have to continue their work long after the sun has set. But the Bill is calculated to bring about a much desired improvement so far as our urban population is concerned. It will enable them, at a certain period of the year, to rise: much earlier than they do at present, and also to retire to rest proportionately earlier in the evening. Every day we behold the spectacle of a valuable amount of sunlight going to waste while people are peacefully sleeping. At present we are slaves to the clock, and i t is to overcome this enslavement that the Bill is introduced. The advantages to be derived from i t are manifold. In addition to providing opportunities for utilizing daylight while people are engaged in their daily occupations, i t will confer a great benefit upon those who work in buildings in the large cities of the Commonwealth. By reason of the fact that they will commence and cease work an hour earlier in the summer time than would otherwise be the case, i t is . obvious that they will perform their allotted task under more agreeable conditions as to temperature.

Then again, the Bill will affect a great saving in the matter of artificial light. The evidence given ' by the Railways Commissioners before the Select Committee which inquired into this matter in Victoria was to the effect that this innovation would result in a saving of £1,700 a year in their lighting bill. It is clear, therefore, that when i t is extended to ail the other Departments of State, as well as to private individuals, there will be material benefits conferred by the operation of this Bill. In the country districts, too, its advantages will be manifest. Children who have to travel long distances to school will arrive there when the air is much cooler than i t will be an hour later in the morning, and, consequently, their day will be spent under improved conditions so far as temperature is concerned. Indeed, advantages will be derived from the Bill which have not been properly assessed up to date. I believe that honorable senators are thoroughly in accord with the principle underlying i t . It has already been introduced in the Old Country, and also in Tasmania, with good results. The reason why this Parliament is taking the initiative in the matter is obvious. The State interests are so interdependent that unless the Central Authority institutes this reform very little benefit w ill he derived from its adoption piecemeal. Seeing that the railway systems between all States are being linked up, the necessity for in troducing such an innovation becomes the more imperative. The transcontinental line will be completed within the next few months.- But Victoria could not move in this matter with benefit to its citizens unless New South Wales and South Australia took similar action, and, consequently, the Commonwealth is abundantly justified in introducing this reform.

talk.start.para: . - So far as the principle of the Bill is concerned, it is not necessary to say anything about it. We should just put it through. But I desire to ask a question which was put by Senator Ready a moment or two ago. I observe that the measure is limited to the duration of the war and six months thereafter. If it is to be so limited I submit that, on the termination of the war, we shall lose the benefit of what should prove a very useful measure.
We can amend the Constitution by means of a referendum.

But referendums do not always result as we would like them to result. If i t be true that we have not the constitutional power to enact this legislation in ordinary times, and that our authority will terminate with the close of the war, I would suggest that this is one of the matters in respect of which the States ought to invest this Parliament with power to legislate in the way that is now proposed. When once thi9 practice of daylight saving has been adopted, I am sure that even the most sluggish members of the community will not be aware of its existence. Therefore I strongly urge upon the Minister - i f we have not the authority in normal times to enact this form of legislation - t o open up negotiations with the States inviting them to endow us with the necessary power.

. - This is one of those measures to which I attach very little importance. I happened to be in the Old Country recently when a similar Bill was brought into operation, and scarcely any one knew anything about it. I quite recognise that it is possible to save money by dispensing with artificial light for a certain period of the year. I am glad that the Commonwealth has taken action to make this, practice uniform throughout Australia. When I was serving my. time, and for some years afterwards, I used to start work at 6 o'clock in the morning during seven months of the year, and at 7 o'clock in the morning during five months of the year. But the wiseacres in the persona of our employers came along and said, " You must all start work at the one time, namely, 8 o'clock." As, a result we lost an hour's daylight.. We had a strike in opposition to the employers' orders - a strike which lasted ten weeks - and we were defeated.- But I am pleased to know that we are now going to revert to the ideal of the trade unionists of thirty years ago. When in England I heard the story of an old lady who would not put her old clock back because it had " told the truth for 100 years, and she could not bear it to tell a lie"; but she had put her little clock back, as it was made in Germany, and was used to lying.

. - I congratulate the Government on bringing forward the Bill, even at this late hour of the session. We have had a little experience in Tasmania of daylight saving, and saving on our light bills. There was considerable opposition to the reform in Tasmania when the Bill was first introduced, but that has almost entirely disappeared. To Captain Giblin, ex-member of the House of Assembly, now at the front with the 40th Battalion, is due the credit for getting the Bill through, after a long and strenuous fight. It seems a small thing to put the clock forward an hour, but the alteration has been appreciated very highly in Tasmania, as I have been told by a number of workers there in the last month or two. When they knock off at 5 o'clock they have nearly five hours of daylight for recreation or amusement. That alone, without the other savings stated, would justify the putting forward of the clock in the beautiful summer climate of the Commonwealth. Another health advantage which has not been touched on is that it gets one to bed an hour earlier every night. We go to bed at 11 o'clock, as usual, although it is really 10 o'clock, so that the Bill is . really, a legislative inculcation of the old adage, " Early to bed and early to rise makes a man healthy, wealthy, and wise." Doctors speak very highly of the Bill for health reasons.

speech.para: We, in Tasmania, have led Australia in this reform, and, in consequence, have been under a great difficulty because our time has been an hour different from mainland time. All the boats sailing to and from Tasmania nave kept mainland time, but the time of departure has had Eb be advertised in the press in Tasmanian time.- Other complications arose, particularly in the sending of telegrams and cables. The closing of the post-offices had to be extended in Tasmania by one hour to keep the time uniform, and' I believe this caused a little friction as far as telegraphic arrangements were concerned, which had to be adjusted. All these disadvantages will disappear with a uniform Act. I hope the Government will look into the constitutional question raised by Senator Millen, so that, instead of being only a temporary war measure, this reform may be permanently grafted upon the national life of the people of Australia.

talk.start.para: . - Senator Millen seems to be under the impression that this measure has been introduced in consequence or on account of the war, and for its duration only. If that is the case, the validity of the legislation can be seriously challenged, because no such ground or' justification is shown in the measure for submitting it and passing it into law. Any authority that we have for passing legislation of this character is given under section 51 of the Constitution, in the paragraph dealing with astronomical and meteorological matters. 1 have very grave and serious doubt whether the measure is within the competence of the Federal Legislature. Had it been desired to pass a measure of this kind, and make time uniform throughout Australia, even adopting the zone system that applies under present conditions that might have been done by regulation under the War Precautions Act; but whether we have the competence to decide by legislation what shall or shall not be standard time for any particular portion of the Commonwealth is very much open to question.
We are for clock time only, and not for standard time.

It does not matter whether i t is clock, standard, mean, solar or any other time. When I was in the Old Country recently they had just adopted a system of daylight saving. For seven or eight years there had been a movement by certain gentlemen in England to get some such system established. At first those who promoted the system were laughed at as fanatics, but when i t had been considered t and reported on by a Committee of the House of Commons, and the report had been circulated throughout the Empire, the subject was taken up and pushed forward. At the same time, I doubt whether any honorable member of this Parliament thought that it was competent for us to deal with the matter. Except under the astronomical or meteorological power, I do not see exactly how we could have assented our competence to deal with the subject. The question of whether we are going to save daylight at one end of the day or the other depends very much on the habits, occupations, and inclinations of various individuals. In England we often found at the end of the day that, after we had had dinner— and i t was much lighter there up to 9 o'clock at night than i t is here now - w e did not feel inclined to go to a place of entertainment. It seemed to be breaking into the day. One had the impression that he was going to a matinee. When the darkness came down, i t was night, and fairly late. People in trade and business, and especially those who cater for the wants of the people at certain hours of the day, will feel the effect of this alteration in the hours of the clock, not for one season, but for two or three. That is one reason why i t is desirable, as Senator Millen suggested, that we should be assured that what we are doing in this regard may be permanent. It will greatly affect those who have invested their savings in various enterprises, particularly people with very small capital, who are endeavouring to cater for the wants of what I may call a flitting community, and are dependent on the returns they get "from these hours in the evening. Tt is all very well to say that, although i t will be necessary to get up an hour earlier in the morning, we shall have three or four hours' leisure in the evening. It will not appeal to people who have invested money in various localities around the cities, and are dependent on catering for the wants of the community between the hours of, say, half-past 7 and 9 o'clock. Those are the people who will be most seriously affected by the alteration of the hours of the clock. Captain Giblin, when in the House of Assembly in Tasmania, took a great deal of interest in this matter, and I assisted him personally here to some small extant in getting on the track of reports and various other matters dealing with the question so far as the House of Commons was concerned. I have a first and second copy of the Bill presented to the Tasmanian Parliament. I have here, also, a copy of the Bill now under consideration by this Chamber. It has been the custom as long as I remember for every clause of any Bill presented to either House of the Federal Parliament to contain under the marginal notes a reference to corresponding existing legislation on the subject. This Bill does not contain a single reference of the kind, either to Imperial or Tasmanian legislation. Yet I can read out clause upon clause of the Tasmanian Bill, and show where, word for word, this Bill has been taken from it. The draftsman, or the Government, have not had the decency or the honour to give credit to Captain Giblin, or the Legislature of Tasmania.

Though this is rather a lengthy Bill, it contains few or no principles. It simply provides machinery whereby the grand principle embodied in the taxing Act may be carried out. The main principle of the measure is to prevent persons from dodging the tax. It prescribes what societies and entertainments shall be taxed, and defines an entertainment to include " any exhibition, performance, lecture, amusement, game or sport for admission to which payment is made." The exemptions are set out in clause 12, as follows : -

quote.para: Entertainments tax shall not he charged on payments for admission to any entertainment where the Commissioner is satisfied -

item.label: (a)
item.para: that the whole of the takings thereof are devoted to philanthropic, religious, or charitable purposes without any charge on the takings for any expenses of the entertainment; or

item.label: (b)
item.para: that the entertainment is of a wholly educational character (any question on that ' point to be determined, in case of difference, by the Commissioner) ; or

item.label: (c)
item.para: that the entertainment is intended only for the amusement of children, and that the charge is not more than 1d. for each person; or

item.label: (d)
item.para: that the entertainment is provided for partly educational or partly scientific purposes by a society, institution, or committee not conducted or established for profit.

speech.para: The last exemption will include agricultural societies - that is, where no payment is made to members of the committee; but the ordinary agricultural society as conducted in Australia will be exempt from taxation under this measure. Of course, the charities, children's bazaars, and so on are also exempted. There is another clause of some little importance, and that is clause 13, which provides for a refund of the tax in certain cases. It says -

quote.para: Where the Commissioner is satisfied that the whole of the net proceeds of an entertainment are devoted to philanthropic, religious, or charitable purposes, and that the whole of the expenses of the entertainment do not exceed 50 per centum of the receipts, he shall repay to the proprietor the amount of the entertainments tax paid in respect of the entertainment.

speech.para: A refund of the amount of the tax will be granted where the entertainment is held purely for philanthropic purposes. A refund is provided in another case.

quote.para: Provided that when the Commissioner is satisfied that, owing to adverse climatic conditions the expenses of an entertainment for philanthropic, religious, or. charitable purposes in respect of which payments for admission have been made exceed 50 per centum of the receipts, the Commissioner shall repay to the proprietor the amount of the entertainments tax paid in respect of the entertainment.

speech.para: Where a fete or a gathering has Deen organized, and owing to adverse weather conditions certain expense has been undertaken by the parties interested, as they are acting purely from a philanthropic motive, that is for the purpose of raising money for an institution, a refund to that amount will be granted. Most of the other provisions are merely machinery provisions for an effective check upon the revenue.

talk.start.para: . - Taking advantage of the brief interval which occurred just now, I asked the Minister a question as to what entertainments were exempted by the provisions he has read ; and I assume from the statement he made just now, that paragraph 6 of clause 12 was intended to supply the information I was seeking. I want to ask the Minister to be very clear on this point, because I think it would be defeating the purpose of Parliament if we attempted to levy the tax on agricultural shows. Although the Minister says that they are exempt, as I think they ought to be, he put a qualification on that exemption; but, apart from the qualification, I am not quite clear, although I accept, his statement as to the intention, that the Bill does exempt these institutions. Clause 12 provides, amongst other things, that the tax shall no't be charged on payments for admission to any entertainment where the Commissioner is satisfied

item.label: (d)
item.para: that the entertainment is provided for partly . educational or partly scientific purposes by a society, institution, or committee not conducted or established for profit.

speech.para: I see many difficulties there in regard to these institutions. The question is whether one would say that an agricultural or horticultural show is partly scientific or partly educational. The Commissioner might take a different view of the matter. When it comes to a question of being conducted for a profit, many of these shows make a profit at one gathering. They do not exist for profit-making, and, on the whole, whatever profits they make go to the improvement of their large grounds. Nevertheless, they make a profit, and it was out of the profits that the Royal Agricultural Society at Sydney built up their magnificent grounds and improvements. I notice that in paragraph 3 of section 10 the South Australian Act of 1916 exempts these shows. It reads as. follows: -

quote.para: Amusements duty shall not be charged on payments for admission to any agricultural, horticultural, floricultural, poultry, dog, or other like show.

speech.para: That -provision is clear and explicit. I ask the Minister to consider before we come to the Committee stage whether it would not be better to incorporate words of that kind, or, at any rate, to amplify the wording of the clause as it stands.

talk.start.para: I am inclined to disagree with the "Leader of the Liberal party in this matter. I am inclined to think that in a time of war the people who conduct agricultural shows will feel aggrieved if they are put apart from others and are not allowed to contribute towards the upkeep of the war. This is no time for half measures. This is no time to exempt some persons because they are engaged in a show or in an exhibition of produce, or in a high-jump exhibition, or in a trotting match. That is of very great educational advantage. These taxation measures are introduced for war purposes. I almost think that i t is an insult to agricultural societies to exempt them at such a time as the present. This is a time when there should be no exemptions from a contribution towards the war. The surprising thing to me is that these shows can be carried on as if there were no war at all. We have just passed a measure that will take 25 per cent, more from incomes which are already heavily taxed. That makes me think that if we are generous with one hand we are grasping with- the other. I do not think that any one connected with agricultural shows or other forms of amusement will take exception to an entertainments tax. I believe that the spirit of the people will be disappointed if the Government exempt any one at the present time.

.- Senator Millenhas nut forth a plea for agricultural societies. If the Government are to be moved by that plea, I would point out to them that once they open the door to exemptions they cannot stop there. From time to time in Victoria there is held an exhibition of a highly-important character for the . purpose of helping onward Australian industries. It is held under the auspices of the Australian Natives Association in the Exhibition Building here, and is very educational. If the Government once open the door in regard to exemptions, it will be very difficult to say where to stop. The exhibition I referred to is not run for a profit, but a charge for admission is made. There have been two or three exhibitions held under the auspices of the Australian Natives Association. The exhibitions have had a highly educational interest to visitors, and a very big effect in encouraging Australian manufactures in different parts of the Commonwealth. They have helped to create a patriotic sentiment in Australia that was not so strongly manifested before the Australian Natives Association took the matter in hand.
I , think that that exhibition is exempt under the clause.
I understood from the Minister the other day that the tax would be levied in respect to any exhibition, performance, lecture, amusement, game, or sport for admission to which payment is made.
- Paragraph d of clause 12 exempts the kind of exhibition to which you refer \ and I want agricultural shows put on the same ground.
Paragraph d of clause 12 exempts the kind of exhibition to which you refer \ and I want agricultural shows put on the same ground.
- Do the profits, if there have been any profits from such exhibitions, go to the funds of the Australian Natives Association?

The profits, if there be any, go to a fund which is utilized for the purpose of extending the association's' sphere of influence in this and similar exhibitions. I do not think that any society which conducts exhibitions of this character ought to come under this measure.
- They are exempt under clause 12, and I want to put agricultural shows on the same list.

That opens up a big subject. Prior to the war the Royal Agricultural Society of Victoria had an annual exhibition on their grounds at Flemington. In addition to the educational advantages which a number of visitors derived from the exhibition, ther was a very varied programme, and substantial monetary prizes were offered for high jumps and other things. If this measure were confined to agricultural societies which hold annual shows for educational purposes, and for the advancement of agricultural, pastoral, and horticultural interests, I would not have the slightest objection to an exemption being made. But in the case of some shows where they have a very varied programme, and because of the programme the profits are sometimes pretty large, I do not know why they should be exempt from this tax.

. - In the various States demonstrations in connexion with which sports are held are arranged every year by trade societies in celebration of the Eight Hours Day. The proceeds in some cases are used entirely for the purpose of completing partially erected trades halls. I am not sure that such demonstrations and sports would be covered by paragraph d of clause 12.
They are covered by clause 13
The p proceeds of the demonstrations are not divided amongst the members of the societies arranging them, and I should like to be assured that they will be exempt from the taxgatherer.
- Should not all these points be considered in Committee?
They would be much more fittingly dealt with in Committee, but as they are relevant to the B ill , I cannot rule their discussion out of order.

Ther e is another form of entertainment to which I would like to refer. The Railways Commissioners at various times arrange for excursions, and excursions are also arranged by the shipping companies. No provision appears to have been made for the imposition of a tax on the proceeds of thes ventures, and so far as I can see they are not included in the exemptions. It is very desirable that we should know whether the very substantial returns which are occasionally derived from these ventures will be liable to the entertainment tax. Of course, this whole business is very objectionable to me. It is a form of taxation to which I am opposed, and i t is calculated to produce, comparatively-speaking, a miserable amount of revenue. The Government are prepared to increase the income-tax, and they propose a tax on entertainment tickets; yet they know that the lands of this country are worth £446,000,000.. It is a standing disgrace that the Government do not come down to this Chamber and ask us to impose a tax upon community-created values.
Order!

- I am glad that Senator Findley raised' the question he did in connexion with paragraph d of clause 12, under which the Assistant Minister has said that shows conducted by agricultural societies will be exempt from this taxation. Though that is not quite clear to me, I accept the assurance of the Minister. I hope we shall have a similar assurance in respect of the Australian Natives' Association Exhibition, to which Senator Findley has referred, and 'which is held on the 26th January in this State. I am doubtful whether that exhibition, which is largely scientific and educational, will be covered by paragraph d of clause 12. I hope that before the Bill goes into Committee the Assistant Minister will be able to five us some assurance on the point. Last year the exhibition was run at a pretty severe financial loss, but this year it is hoped there will be a profit.

. - We have not had much time to look into this Bill, and I therefore require a little information. I should like to know whether it is the intention of the Government to tax complimentary tickets and cards of invitation for entertainments for admission to persons who do not hold such tickets or cards are obliged to pay. If it is not the intention of the Government to tax such tickets and cards it should be. I should like to know also whether totalizator tickets, and tickets for Tattersall's sweeps, from which a considerable revenue is derived, are to be liable to this taxation, or whether those who derive large profits from this source of revenue are to be allowed to go scot-free !

. - Questions in dispute as to liability to taxation under clause 12 are to be determined by the Commissioner, from whose decision there is no appeal. I have the authority of the Acting Commissioner to say that, in his opinion, clause 12 does cover agricultural shows, and we may, therefore, accept that as final. They are partly educational and partly scientific. The Australian Natives Association Exhibition referred to by Senators Findley and Blakey would certainly come under the same determination, as it is not held for the purpose of making a profit. The whole matter depends on the question whether the fete, carnival, race-meeting, cricket or football match, or sports meeting is run for profit. Tickets for admission to a professional football match would undoubtedly be taxed, but if there were a guarantee that a particular match was an amateur game, it would be a question for the Commissioner to decide whether it would not be exempt.
What about the eight hours demonstrations?

It is carried out purely for charity, but in such a case there is a condition as to the amount of expenses incurred. In the case of an Eight Hours Day gala run for charitable purposes, as i t always is
- The Minister is speaking only of Victoria.
—If such a demonstration were carried out for profit, I suppose the tickets for admission would be liable to the tax, and this would depend upon the determination of the Commissioner.
- What if it is held for the benefit of a trades hall fund?

If a .demonstration is carried out by an eight hours committee, or by any one else for profit, and not for charity, the rickets of admission would be liable to taxation. Under clause 13 the Commissioner has power to refund taxation where he is satisfied that the whole of the net proceeds of an entertainment are devoted to philanthropic, religious, or charitable purposes, and the expenses do not exceed 50 per cent, of the receipts, and also in a case where, because of adverse climatic conditions, the expenses of an entertainment for those purposes exceed 50 per cent, of the receipts. Senator McDougall has raised the question of complimentary tickets. They could not be taxed, because, before any ticket is liable to this taxation, i t must have been paid for. The difficulty the honorable senator has raised might be got over by an absolute prohibition of such complimentary tickets 'in the case of any entertainment for admission to which a charge is made. We know that complimentary tickets are often given in these cases, and the societies concerned might be called upon to pay the tax in respect of such tickets, or the visitor to the entertainment would otherwise have to be stopped at the gate, and the amount of the tax collected from him. I ask Senator McDougall not to press for an amendment in that direction.'

quote.para: Entertainments tax shall not be charged on payments for admission to any entertainment where the Commissioner is satisfied -

item.para: that the whole of the takings thereof are devoted to philanthropic, religious, or charitable purposes without any charge on the takings for any expenses of the entertainment; or

item.label: (b)
