talk.start.para: . - I want a little information from the Minister in charge of the Bill. In South Australia a concert is held annually by the children of the State schools, in which as many as a thousand children take part. There is a charge for admission, 'but the whole of the money is devoted to the decoration of the schools throughout the State. This cannot definitely be said to be a charity, nor can it any more definitely be said to be an entertainment run for profit, whilst it is certainly in the interests of education.

If a .demonstration is carried out by an eight hours committee, or by any one else for profit, and not for charity, the rickets of admission would be liable to taxation. Under clause 13 the Commissioner has power to refund taxation where he is satisfied that the whole of the net proceeds of an entertainment are devoted to philanthropic, religious, or charitable purposes, and the expenses do not exceed 50 per cent, of the receipts, and also in a case where, because of adverse climatic conditions, the expenses of an entertainment for those purposes exceed 50 per cent, of the receipts. Senator McDougall has raised the question of complimentary tickets. They could not be taxed, because, before any ticket is liable to this taxation, i t must have been paid for. The difficulty the honorable senator has raised might be got over by an absolute prohibition of such complimentary tickets 'in the case of any entertainment for admission to which a charge is made. We know that complimentary tickets are often given in these cases, and the societies concerned might be called upon to pay the tax in respect of such tickets, or the visitor to the entertainment would otherwise have to be stopped at the gate, and the amount of the tax collected from him. I ask Senator McDougall not to press for an amendment in that direction.'

Frequently there are entertainments held for the entry to which a charge of 6d. is made, whilst an additional 6d. is charged for refreshment. I should like to know whether such entertainments would be liable to this taxation?

The way in which a mixed spree such as an entertainment which is followed by a dance and buns and coffee will be viewed by the Commissioner i t is impossible for me to say. An entertainment of that sort may be conducted by a dance-room committee for their own profit, in which case the proceeds will be taxed. On the other hand, i t may be run for the benefit of a hospital, or of the Red Cross fund, in which case the proceeds will not be taxed.

-I would like to be clear as to the position that will be occupied by the annual demonstration of the Eight Hours Union. The Assistant Minister has stated that in Victoria the demonstration is conducted purely on charitable lines. But Victoria is the only State in the Commonwealth which has enacted legislation in that direction. In the other States, the annual demonstration is conducted in the capitals and towns in which there is an Eight Hours Union of the various trades and occupations. If any profit results from the demonstration, it is devoted, not to the organizations, but to the erection of a hall, in- which they may meet. I do not know under what heading such entertainments will come.
That is a sort of charity which begins at home.

But I would like the honorable senator to understand that these trade societies cannot meet in those halls without paying rental for the rooms which they occupy, and the whole of the proceeds derived from such rental, and also from the annual demonstration, is devoted to- extending or improving the building which is used by these particular organizations. I think that the- Assistant Minister should tell us whether' such entertainments will be taxed under this B ill .

. - I understand that an institution holding a benefit carnival, such as the Trades Hall, will not be exempt from the operation of the Bill, unless the Commissioner determines that the carnival is of a charitable, educational, or scientific character. Where an eight hours demonstration is run for charitable purposes, the proceeds will be exempt from taxation, but where it is run for the benefit of a building fund it will be taxed.

. - I should like to know whether the tickets of admission to social and other forms of entertainment which are held by committees of the Liberal party to assist in defraying the cost of their election campaigns will be exempt from taxation?

. - I would point out to the honorable senator that it is not so much a question of the nature of the function as it is of its object and purpose. If the Women's National League hold a garden party, for example, and the profits are used for political purposes, they will certainly be taxed.

.- It seems to me that there ought to be some provision in the- Bill to exempt from taxation all Eight Hours Demonstrations. I have had some experience of the little demonstration that is held in Tasmania. The profits from it are really nil, and the demonstration is practically financed by voluntary contributions. I know that these contributions amount to £50 or £60, and that the whole takings do not exceed £120. It would be cruel to tax a demonstration of that sort, which is not run for the purposes of private profit. If a profit should accrue from the exhibition, it is devoted to providing, a hall for the various trade organizations. But that profit is represented entirely by voluntary contributions.

.- I think that any profits derived by trade organizations in Australia from their annual fetes in connexion with the eight hours principle should be exempted from taxation for the same reason that the profits derived from an exhibition under the auspices of the Australian Natives Association are to be exempt. In Victoria, for many, years, Labour has celebrated the Eight Hours Day in a way worthy of the occasion. There is, in connexion with that demonstration, an art union, and thousands of tickets are sold which enable their purchasers to witness the sports that are held in the arena and the pother amusements which are provided - in the main building. After the demonstration a balance-sheet is presented, and a certain amount is devoted to State charities. A statement was recently published in the press to the effect that the Peacock Government do not intend to approve of the holding of any future art unions in connexion with the Eight Hours Demonstration; but whether they will live long enough to do anything further in the direction suggested, I do not know. At the present time, they are between the devil and the briny. Their fate hangs in the balance. Some say that their days are numbered, and I hope that they are.

speech.para: But if the Eight Hours' Union is not permitted to hold an art union in connexion with future demonstrations, a certain sum of money will have to be provided for the expenditure which must necessarily be incurred, and any profits resulting therefrom will, according to the statement of the Assistant Minister, be taxed.

talk.start.para: The tax will not be levied on the profits.
That is so. I will be levied on the proceeds of admission.
- On the gross takings.
The tax will be levied on those who pass through the turnstiles and on the tickets that are sold if tickets be issued.
- Irrespective of whether a profit or loss is made ?
Yes; , but seeing that there will be an exemption in connexion wifch the Australian Natives Association, why should an invidious distinction he drawn in the case of the Eight Hours Demonstration?
I s not the Eight Hours Demonstration in the streets an educational one?
I hold that i t is not merely of an educational, but of a scientific character.
Then it will be exempt.
Under what provision of the Bill?
Under the clause to which the honorable senator has referred several times.

The Assistant Minister has stated that they will not be exempt, and he has obtained his information from an officer who holds a responsible position in the Land Tax Office. If is very doubtful whether the Commissioner of Taxes will rule that these demonstrations are of an educational o scientific character.
It depends upon the purposes to which the profits are to be devoted.
I do not see how that affects the position.
- If they are to be devoted to charitable purposes, it is one thing; but if they are to be devoted to purposes of private profit, it is another.

In these cases the profits are utilized by the committees to make additions to existing buildings, and where no extensions are required, a fund is created for the erection of a trades hall. All doubts ought to be removed here, and now as to whether the Eight Hours demonstrations are to come under the category of the B ill . I do not want to move an amendment if I can get an assurance from the Minister on the subject. If ' ' I find that they are to come within the provisions of the Bill I shall take' an opportunity of - seeing ' whether they cannot be made exempt.

. - Several cases have been cited where hardships might inure if the provisions of the Bill were made applicable to the receipts in connexion with particular forms of entertainment. An important institution exists in this Commonwealth which does not exist anywhere else, in the world - the annual Inter-State eight-oar race - which has been intermitted since the war began. I do not expect the Minister to be in a position to say whether any particular institution will or will not come within the purview of the Bill in the opinion of the Commissioner, but I take it that the Commissioner, in exercising his discretion under clause 12, will to a certain extent be guided by the general feeling of Parliament when the Bill was going through.
I s not the international race held on the Thames and elsewhere of much greater importance than the one you mention ?

This is the only institution of its kind in the world. Six States send their respective eight-oar crews, Queensland being exempted if the race is rowed on the Swan, and Western Australia exempted if the race is rowed on the Brisbane. In those cases the States named can stay out without forfeiting their right to compete in the following year. The oarsmen are all amateurs, and the main source of revenue for preserving the race comes from the admission fee paid for seats on the boats which the organization at the particular centre where the race is rowed charters, and which alone are permitted to follow the race. The charge runs from £1 upwards. According to the entertainments tax that was passed last night, the tax on those tickets would be Is. 8d., or more. The money derived from the charges on the boats goes to the local association in aid of their fund to carry on the event; but, as a matter of fact, whenever a State has the honour of having the race rowed on its river, the local association has to go round to the friends of rowing a long time beforehand and ask them to put their hands in their pockets to enable i t to finance the affair. No profit is derived by any person or organization. If you ask a man who is going to follow the race to pay £1 Is. 8d., instead of. £1, he will -hesitate a great deal more than the man who has to pay Is. Id., instead of Is., to go to an entertainment. The event calls together annually over a distance of 2,000 miles the trained young rowers of the Commonwealth, who do not benefit a penny-piece by their achievements. The Oxford and Cambridge race is rowed within a comparatively short distance of the respective universities. The definition says, " 'Entertainment' includes any exhibition, performance, lecture, amusement, game, or sport for admission to which payment is made." Many people may go to see portions of the race from the banks of the river, but those who want to see i t from start to finish invariably go on one of the vessels which the local association charters. I hope that the Minister,will take the matter into consideration and see that when the races are restored after the war they are treated by the Commissioner equally as well as the Eight Hours demonstration.

. - It 'has been distinctly stated that the agricultural societies throughout the States will be exempt from this taxation. There are agricultural shows held annually, not only in the capitals, but in almost every town along the coast and inland. They do not make a great deal of money, but they have a certain amount of ground, and on its improvement expend whatever profit is made. In addition to Brisbane, shows are held at Ipswich, Toowoomba, Maryborough, Rockhampton, Bundaberg, Mackay, and other places by agricultural and industrial societies, but in all those places there' is also another annual demonstration which brings the people into the centres. That is the demonstration bv the Labour orrganizations, which has exactly the same effect, and to a great extent a similar influence. No person or individual organization makes a profit out of these - gatherings. In most places the , State has granted a piece of land on which the organizations are to erect a building. Their principal means of raising funds is their annual demonstration, and the profits are ' always used to improve the land and erect buildings for the benefit of the organized labour in the district, just as the annual agricultural and industrial shows are held for the benefit of the people engaged in agriculture and industry. An honorable senator from South Australia has called my attention to the fact that a wealthy man in Adelaide paid off the debt on the Trades Hall in Adelaide, but in most other cases in Australia numbers of people by attending these demonstrations provide a certain amount of money which is used to pay for or improve the hall.
We did not get the land from the Government

In some cases in Queensland the State has not given the land, but in others i t has. It was also given in Sydney and Melbourne. Certainly if the whole of the agricultural societies with their annual demonstrations are to be exempt, the annual demonstrations of organized labour should also be exempt from taxation of this description.
. - In paragraph c of the clause there appears the following: -

quote.para: That the entertainment is intended only for the amusement of children, and that the charge is not more than Id. for each person; or

speech.para: It would appear that the Bill was drawn up at a, time when 6d. and even 3d. tickets were included, but tickets up to 6d. have been exempted, and I want to know now if entertainments given by private showmen to school children will be included. It seems to me necessary to alter this paragraph in order to make the Bill conform, with the other measure which we have passed.

talk.start.para: . - The words complained of by the honorable senator are useless, but they can do no harm, and I would ask the honorable senator not to press the matter.
—Wh y not send the Bill back if an error is discovered in this Chamber ?

I have no objection to that course, and I admit the desirability of having the Bill strictly correct. Referring to the point raised by Senator Turley, I feel sure he will not accuse me of lacking in sympathy for the proposal, because I am very well aware that in some countries of the world halls are provided free of charge to workers' organizations. But in this Bill' we are laying down a principle concerning carnivals, bazaars, and various other forms of amusements, and the question arises whether a carnival or eight hours fete organized for the purpose of benefiting the building fund, should or should not be taxed. If i t can be shown that trades halls are not used for educational or scientific purposes—thoug h meetings are held in such buildings for educational and scientific objects— I do not see why they cannot be included in the same category as, say, cricket clubs in the metropolitan area where, as a rule, the proceeds are divided by three, each club interested in the ground getting 33 per cent., and using the money generally for the development and improvement of the property. I trust that the suggestion will not be pressed, and I understand that the Leader of the Liberal party in another House practically withdrew any suggestions that an exemption would be claimed under this heading.

. - I would suggest that Senator Senior press the question he has raised. The Minister says it does not matter very much, and, that' being so, I do not see why another place should not accept the amendment at once. It would indicate, at all events, that we are endeavouring to harmonize our legislation, and if we are here simply to wait on another place, and are expected to say " ditto," we might just as well go home.
- I will adopt the suggestion of Senator Keating, and move -

quote.para: That in paragraph c the words " One penny " be left out, with a view to insert in lieu thereof the word " sixpence."

debate.para: Bill reported with an amendment: report adopted.

talk.start.para: . - I understand that we shall have to wait for some time for clean copies of the Income Tax Assessment Bill. There are only about half-a-dozen available.
In view of the state of business, and in order that clean copies of the Income Tax Assessment Bill may be obtained, I suspend the sitting of the Senate until 10.45 p.m.

speech.para: Sitting suspended from 9.45 to 10.15 p.m.

debate.para: Bill received from the House of Representatives.

talk.start.para: Before the Senate considers the message from the other House, I desire to say that when I suspended the sitting at 9.45 p.m. I understood that fair prints of this Bill would not be available for about an hour. Soon after the suspension I learned that fair prints of the B ill had arrived, and, therefore, I took the liberty of calling the Senate together by ringing the bell. If any honorable senator, either on his own behalf or on behalf of any other honorable senator, objects, I will not allow the proceedings to be resumed until such time as that to which I had suspended the sitting has arrived, namely, 10.45 p.m. As no honorable senator objects, either on his own behalf or on behalf of any other honorable senator, business will proceed. Standing and Sessional Orders suspended, and Bill read a first time.
. - I move -

speech.para: That this Bill be now read a second time.

This is really the complement to the -Bill which was recently passed fixing the rate of income tax for the present year. The object of the measure is to effect certain amendments in the principal Act, which have been found, as the result of practical experience gained by the officers, to be necessary for the successful working of the Act, and to remove those little frictions which from time to time arise in the working of. a large Act of this character. The Bill makes one or two amendments in the principal Act. Where, for instance, a man is allowed a deduction for a dependant the rate Has been increased from £13 to £26. Likewise where a man is allowed to make a deduction for each of his children the amount has been increased from. £13 to £16. It' has been found necessary to amplify the provisions of the principal Act with regard to official secrecy, so as to enable a free interchange and exchange of information between Commonwealth and State officers. This amplification will lighten the work a good deal, and will be the initial step in leading to what we trust will be the harmonizing and cheapening of these services, as well as making more effective provision in that regard.

talk.start.para: What clause deals with that?
Claus e 3 provides for officers to observe secrecy. The provision reads—

quote.para: Notwithstanding anything contained in this section, the Commissioner, the Assistant Commissioner, or a Deputy Commissioner, may communicate any matter which comes to -his knowledge in the performance of 'his official duties to the Commissioner of Income Tax for any State who has been authorized by legislation to afford similar information to the Commissioner, the Assistant Commissioner, or a Deputy Commissioner.

talk.start.para: - That is a reciprocal provision 1

It will be reciprocal between the States and the Commonwealth. It is, perhaps, a bigger alteration than i t appears on paper in the work of practical administration, and we are hopeful of making a. further advance in that direction in the future. The method of assessing the taxable- income of companies is to be amended by inserting a provision that companies are to pay tax on assessable income distributed to members or share or stock-holders who 'are absentees. The companies will be able to pay the income tax, and subsequently deduct the amounts from those with whom the dividends have been paid.
- Insurance 'companies are to be included in the provision.

Marin e insurance companies are to be included in the provision dealing with insurance companies which previously only related to fire insurance. The special deductions allowed by the principal Act are proposed to be repealed,, and new provisions inserted. The following statement will show the difference between the existing and proposed reductions: —

continue.para: Under the proposed scheme it is estimated that the taxation will disappear at £500 in regard, to income from personal exertion, and also income derived from property.

talk.start.para: - What clause deals with that?
Clause 11
- What will be the difference in the taxation, taking three or four instances of incomes ranging from £500 to £1,000?
I regret that at the moment I am not able to give the information, but I understand that i t averages about 25 per cent, all round.

quote.para: Section 11 of the principal Act is amended -

item.label: (a)
item.para: by omitting from paragraph (e) the words "the War Loan Act (No. 1) 1915," and inserting in their stead the words "a Commonwealth War Loan"; . . . . . ,, .

talk.start.para: .--In this clause I notice a 'provision amending the principal Act by omitting from paragraph e of section 11, the words " The War Loan Act(No. 1) 1915," and inserting in their stead the. words, "a Commonwealth War Loan." Owing to the brief period in which the Bill has been in our hands, I am not quite clear as to the effect of that amendment. But if, as it seems to me, it is intended to incorporate in this measure a permanent exemption for all future war loans, the Committee should be informed of that, so that we shall not unwittingly commit ourselves to a declaration of policy as to future war loans. I would like the Minister to say whether this provision is merely intended to legalize the second war loan, or whether it is intended to cover future war loans.

. - The Government feel that in granting the exemption under the War Loan Act, both Houses deliberately led the people of this country to believe that such exemption would be granted in respect to all war loans. We found that the moment it was intimated that there was going to be a tax on war bonds and inscribed stock the drop in their value was very marked indeed, indicating that we would have to . pay at least 41/2 per cent for war money. The Government felt that they were under an obligation, not so much to a previous Government as to the decision of Parliament to exempt war loans from taxation.

. - I am sorry to hear the statement of the Minister, because it raises the whole question. I have no desire in doing so to cut across the conditions under which previous loans -may have been issued, and if this provision could be so amended as to apply only to those loans which have been floated, I would be content to rest there. If we are now asked under the guise of an Income Tax Bill, to tie our hands as to future loans, I am unable to consent to the provision. What I suggest to the Government is that they should cover all the loans issued to date, and then when a fresh loan is about to be floated, the Parliament will have another opportunity of considering and determining the conditions under which future loans shall be issued. In the short time at my disposal, I have been' unable to ascertain exactly how this provision fits in with the principal Act, but in order to put ourselves on a proper footing, I move -

speech.para: That the words " a Commonwealth War Loan " be- left out.
I do not quite know what the effect of their omission would be.

talk.start.para: What do you propose to put in their place?

Nothing , because 1 am throwing on the Government the responsibility, the time being too brief for me to look into the matter. All that I am trying to do is to bring the consideration of this Bill to a standstill until we have had an opportunity to study its provisions, and to get from the Government a clearer definition than we have. I am utterly opposed to this policy of saying that for all time these loans shall be exempt from what I regard as a very fair share of taxation.

. - It was the same lines in the Bill which arrested my attention. I recognise the difficulty with which the Government are confronted in reference to this matter. Provision has been made with regard to the first war loan, referred to here as the war loan of 1915 I take it, though I am not quite sure on the point, that the object of the provision is to make applicable to subsequent war loans the provisions that apply to the first war loan in connexion with the exemption from income tax.
Yes

Senator Millen has pointed out that the clause will not only achieve that object, but will go further, and if paragraph a remains as i t stands, it will apply to all future war loans the same provisions as apply to war loan No. 1. And the honorable senator has said that i t is desirable that Parliament should have the opportunity to dictate the terms on which each war loan should be floated in the future. I can quite understand that the Government consider it desirable to promote investments in war loans, rather than in some other enterprise, and one of the inducements to such investment is that the interest accruing from a war loan is exempt from income tax. I think that this is not the hour, and the present are not the conditions, under which the Senate should be asked to at Once ratify such a principle. We are being asked to bind ourselves by the use of the phrase " a .Commonwealth war loan" to apply the same provision to a war loan which might be raised sixteen months or two years hence.- I ask the Assistant Minister to agree to confine the application of this amendment of the existing Act to war loans which have so far been issued, and to refrain from asking the Committee to tie the hands of Parliament with regard to future war loans.

. - Since I spoke I have obtained a copy of the main Act, and I should like, by permission of the Committee, to withdraw my amendment, with a view to submitting it in an amended form. The section of the existing Act which we are by this clause invited to amend reads -

quote.para: The following incomes, revenues, and funds shall he exempt from income tax.

speech.para: And paragraph e of the section which is sought to be amended by this Bill reads -

quote.para: The income derived from bonds, debentures, stock, or other securities of the Commonwealth issued under the provisions of War Loan Act No. 1 1916.

speech.para: We have been asked to amend that, and my desire will be attained if the Committee will negative paragraph a of the clause now under consideration. That will leave the existing Income Tax Assessment Act as it stands in this connexion, and it does exempt war loans issued so far.

talk.start.para: No ; that would cover only war loan No. 1.
- Would not the honorable senator's object be attained by substituting the words " existing Commonwealth war loans " for the words " a Commonwealth war loan " t

In any case, in view of the wording of the section I have quoted from the existing Act, i t is necessary for me to ask leave to withdraw my amendment, in order to substitute for i t an amendment which will have the effect of exempting all war loans issued to date, while leaving the Senate a perfectly free hand to consider any proposals for future borrowing.

speech.para: Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.
Amendment (by Senator MILLEN) proposed—

quote.para: That the words " a Commonwealth War Loan" be- left out, with a view to insert in lieu thereof the words " existing Commonwealth; War Loans."

talk.start.para: - I suggest that the substituted words should be " Commonwealth war loans authorized before 1st January, 1917 ":

Ther e is much in the suggestion of the Assistant Minister, because I am sure honorable senators do not desire that one portion of the bonds or stock of a war loan should be issued under one set of conditions, and another under different conditions. My sole desire, and, I believe, that of the Committee, is not to interfere with what has already been done, whilst leaving Parliament free to consider future loan proposals. I willingly accept the suggestion of the Assistant Minister for the amendment of my amendment.

continue.para: Amendment amended to read as follows:

quote.para: That the words " a Commonwealth War Loan" be left out, with a view to insert in lieu thereof the words " Commonwealth- War Loans authorized up to the first day of January, 1917."

talk.start.para: .- I wish the Committee to be quite clear as to what it is doing. The last war loan authorized was for £50,000,000, and of that amount only about £23,000,000 has been borrowed. I should like to know whether it is the desire' of .honorable senators that the unissued balance of that £50,000,000 loan shall come under this provision or not. Personally, I am inclined to support the Government in this matter, because I know that all the money we can borrow in any way will be required for war purposes. I want to be clear whether the words, " Commonwealth War Loans authorized before 1st January," 1917," will cover the balance of the last war loan that has not yet been floated.

. - The Assistant Minister will correct me if I am wrong, but I take it that the effect of my amendment will be to apply this provision to loans so far authorized. The question is whether the Government are likely to float the balance of the last loan, authorized between this and the 1st January. I do not think, that is at all probable.
—Eve n though the balance is not floated, it has been authorized.

If we are in a difficulty in connexion with this matter, i t is one for which neither I nor the Senate can take any responsibility. I want a clear pronouncement of what will be incorporated in this law. If there is any difficulty in the matter, I suggest that the amendment might be carried in the way I have proposed, and in the transfer of the B ill from the Senate to another place, Ministers may consult with the draftsman and supply an amendment which will meet the object of the Senate.

. - I think the Committee is unanimous, that, as far as money already lent to the Commonwealth is concerned,' we have no desire to disturb the conditions on which it was raised ; but so far as money yet to be raised is concerned, we claim to have a free hand in deciding the terms upon which it shall be raised. If Senator Millen adheres to the use of the word " Authorized " in his amendment, the consequence may be that the balance of £27,000,000 not floated of the war loan for £50,000,000 already authorized will escape the scrutiny of this Parliament, so far. as the conditions upon which it is to be floated are concerned. If that be so, I think the intention of the Committee will not be given effect to.

. - Senator Keating has put the position correctly. The fact is that about £27,000,000 of the last loan authorized by Parliament has not yet been issued, but that loan was advertised as one loan, and the announcement was made to the public that the interest upon the loan would be exempt from State and Federal income tax. I see that with respect to that loan the present Treasurer, in his interim financial statement, said -

quote.para: The proposal already made includes war bonds and inscribed stock as being subject to levy. There are some members who believe that no promise or pledge was given that these bonds should be free from all taxation, and, on examination of the war loan prospectus, that contention can be maintained, as therein it is stated that " all bonds and all transfers of inscribed stock will be free of Commonwealth and State stamp duty, and interest will be free of Commonwealth and State income tax." Clearly they were not to be free from all taxation, but many of the public appear to have been under the . impression that the principal would not be taxed in any way, and the announcement that a levy of one-half per cent, per annum for three years on war bonds, as well as on ordinary wealth, was to be imposed has unsettled the value of these securities, and, in some instances, so I am advised, investments have gone to other countries because of this proposal. The position of the Commonwealth is a dual one. In addition to our intention to increase taxation, we are also a borrower within our territorial limits.

speech.para: We have to consider to what extent certain conditions attached to the loan were advertised.

talk.start.para: My amendment does not touch the yet unissued balance of the last loan authorized.
Yes , i t covers that; and I did not understand that the Committee objected. If honorable senators are prepared to accept the amendment as a compromise, the Government will agree to i t

. - I did not hear the Assistant Minister's concluding remarks. I understand, however, that the acceptance of the amendment will mean that this Parliament will be afforded an opportunity of saying whether all future war loans shall be exempt from taxation.' I do not think that Senator Millen intends that the unsubscribed balance of the loan for £50,000,000, for which applications were recently invited, shall be subject to income tax. Do the Government accept the position that Parliament shall determine whether all future loans shall pay Commonwealth and State income tax?
Yes

.- If I understand the position aright, the amendment will not in any way touch the balance of the war loan which has yet to be issued. If that be so, there is no necessity for that amendment, because whenever any future war loan is projected we shall be free and unfettered.
—Bu t we shall not have any Income Tax B ill before us then. This is the measure which grants the exemption.
- The clause relates to the War Loan Act 1915, and there is a second War Loan Act.

. - The amendment of Senator Millen will certainly improve the clause, but I am not enamoured of the fact that it will exempt from taxation the balance of the loan which has been already authorized. In regard to every war loan that has been issued the prospectus has intimated that the interest accruing from the bonds will be free from income tax. I cannot repudiate that arrangement, but I would point out that we have not issued any prospectus in regard to the balance of the loan that has been already authorized, which balance amounts to £27,000,000.
But a prospectus was issued in reference to the entire loan of £50,000,000.

Technically , my honorable friend is right; but we calle for applications for a loan of £50,000,000, and stated that such applications were to close on a certain date. When that date arrived, the contract was at an end, and we are now at liberty to offer any other terms that we like for the balance of that loan.
- I still think that I can go and buy the bonds.

That is so; but 1 the Treasurer has intimated that he proposes to ask for a fresh loan during the current year. He will issue a fresh prospectus in which i t will be stated that applications to subscribe to the loan will close on a certain date. In my judgment we ought not to commit the Commonwealth any further to the vicious principle of exempting war loans from taxation.
- It is an inducement to people to subscribe the principal.

But what we gain iu one way by adopting that course, we lose in another. We have already floated loans aggregating £141,000,000, and the time is rapidly approaching when a very considerable portion of the income of this country will be derived from interest on money invested in those loans.
- The total loans issued to date do not represent more than about5 per cent, of the annual income of Australia.

It is fortunate that this proposal of the Government was discovered in time to effect an alteration in i t. Every time that the matter comes up I shall protest against the creation in this country of a financial aristocracy which is to be free from taxation. ' A man with £100,000 invested in war bonds is at present exempt from all the expenses of government.
Then put the amount at £1,000,000. Why should a millionaire who has £1,000,000 invested in war bonds be free from taxation?
- We are after the principal.
I will support the amendment, because i t is a long way preferable to the proposal in the B ill , but, at the same time, the whole principle underlying this sort of legislation is rotten.

. - When applications were invited for subscriptions to a war loan of £50,000,000, the people were given to understand that the interest derived from their war bonds would be exempt from income tax, stamp duty, and, indeed, any other form of taxation. Despite these inducements, however, and notwithstanding that the country is engaged in a life-and-death struggle, we got less than half the amount for which we asked'. Now it is proposed that all future war loans shall be launched on a less favorable market. If we tell the public that we intend to charge income tax, stamp duty, and wealth tax on all moneys invested in future war loans, shall we get the £27,000,000 which represents the balance of the loan which has already been authorized ? I do- not think so. In my opinion, it does not matter very much whether we get the money in this fashion or . not, because there is another and far more satisfactory way of raising it, which I shall' be glad to see put into operation.
The honorable senator would be very sorry.

1 would not. I am quite tired of the honorable senator attempting to shield from taxation the men who own the country. I am anxious to see the Commonwealth get as much money as possible to enable it to carry on the war, but I have not the slightest doubt that if we lay i t down that the balance of the loan that has already been authorized shall be subject to income tax and wealth tax
The honorable senator is not at liberty to discuss that matter. He must confine his remarks to the clause under consideration.
It does not very much matter whether the clause is agreed to or not. But I wish to know definitely whether future loans are to be subject to taxation.
- This amendment will not impose taxation on them. It will merely leave Parliament free.
The proposal of the Government will do nothing of the kind. It will subject them to taxation. The amendment of the honorable senator merely relates to loans that have been authorized to date.

. - I wish to congratulate the Senate on the change that has come over it since the last occasion when this matter was discussed. I recollect that whenSenator Mullan first moved an amendment; with a view to subjecting the interest derived from war loans to State and Federal income tax, only two honorable senators supported him. On the second occasion there were five others, who were described as fanatics, to say nothing of those who supported Senator Stewart's proposal for the non-payment of interest on war loans. I welcome Senators Millen and Keating to the convert ranks. It appears to me only fair that income from interest on war loans should be subject to the same taxation as income from any other source. In connexion with the last loan, we invited applications for £50,000,000, but only £23,000,000 was subscribed. I should like to see the balance of that loan subjected to State and Federal income tax. Seeing that the Commonwealth Government called for a loan of £50,000,000 for war purposes, and only £23,000,000 was subscribed, the moneyed shirkers who did not respond to the call should not be shown any consideration now.
They might not have had the money to respond to the call.
Ther e was money here to send to the Argentine for investment, but these financial cold-footers did not think it right to comply with the request made by the Federal Government.
- The amount subscribed was more than the annual income of the ' Commonwealth.

It did not represent all the available liquid assets of the Commonwealth. When the fate of the Commonwealth is involved, as these people tell us it is, the least they can do is to come right up to the scratch, and the remaining £27,000,000 should not be exempt. If a separate appeal is made to obtain it, I will regard i t as to all intents and purposes a new war loan appeal, and it should be subject to income tax. I urge Senator Millen to come right down t bedrock and exempt no further loans for war purposes from Federal income tax.

. - I am afraid Senator Millen will not accomplish the object he has in view. There will be nothing to prevent the Government bringing down a further authorization and exempting loans to be raised under it from income tax.
You would have to get the assent of the Senate.

Therefor e this decision does not bind the Senate or the Government, although some honorable senators fondly imagine that they are tying the hands of the Government in regard to future loan authorizations. It therefore does not matter a straw whether the amendment is passed or not.
- Then agree to it.

Why move an amendment which has no effect? I point out to Senators Mullan and Ferricks that unless they are prepared to bring down a compulsory Loan Bill making men subscribe i t is of no use for them to talk as they have been doing. They know the old adage about bringing a horse to water. If the interest rate is fixed too low men will not give their money. At present, under the threat of a tax of i per cent, on capital, money is going abroad. The average tax under this Bill could be Is. in the £1, or 5 per cent. What sort of an effect, therefore, would that have in driving men to foreign countries to invest their money? As a matter of fact, instead of reducing the interest, we may yet have to pay 8 per cent., as Japan did. We asked for £50,000,000, and offered 4£ per cent. Why did we not get it?
- Because it was not good enough.
That is exactly the reason. We' are simply beating the air over an amendment which will not bind either the Government or Parliament. Senator Millen is leading us up a blind alley.
. - This is a very comprehensive clause, that seems to strike at many- of the principles of the original measure. Will the Minister briefly explain its significance, purpose, and effect?

.- The first two amendments proposed make the intention of the first part of sub-section 1 of section 18 of the principal Act clearer, by specifically stating that the section deals only with assessable income, that is, income which is not exempt, and that the deductions allowable are in respect of expenditure incurred in producing the assessable income. Under amendment c the war-time profits tax payable on the profits of a business earned in 1915-16, and which are being assessed for income tax for 1916-17, will be deductible when ascertaining the taxable income for the 1916-17 assessment. It will be noticed that the new section does not say that the deduction is to be war-time profits tax paid in the year in which the taxable income was derived. The proposal will operate so as to prevent payment of income tax on that part of the profits of the year which will be taken as war-time profits tax. It will authorize the Commissioner of Taxation to, in effect, reopen the income tax assessments based on the 1914-15 income in those cases in which war-time profits tax is also payable on that income, so as to allow refunds of income tax already assessed on that part of the profits which will be taken as war-time profits tax. That is to avoid double taxation. It is proposed to provide in the War-time Profits Tax Assessment Bill a clause authorizing the Commissioner to treat these refunds as a set-off against the amount of war-time profits tax in those cases in which, when the income tax was assessed, it was not practicable .to ascertain the amount of the war-time profits tax which would be deductible. The proviso to - amendment c is a proper one to insert in the Bill, otherwise larger deductions than are justly allowable will be allowed in all those cases in which taxpayers have received refunds on account of overpayment of any of the taxes mentioned.

quote.para: Section nineteen of the principal Act is repealed, and the following section inserted in its stead : - 19. (1) In the case of a person (other than a company, an' absentee, or a person without a dependant) there shall be deducted, in addition to the sums set forth in the last preceding section, the sum of One hundred and fifty-six pounds less Five pounds for every Eleven pounds by which the income . exceeds One hundred and fifty-six pounds.

item.para: When the total taxable income consists partly of income from personal exertion and partly of income from property the deduction under this section shall be apportioned pro rata between the income from each source.

In the case of a person (not being an absentee) without a dependant there shall be deducted, in addition to the sums set forth in the last preceding section, the sum. of One hundred pounds less One pound for every, Four pounds by which the income exceeds One hundred pounds..

talk.start.para: . - We should have a statement from the " Minister as to how the proposed alterations will affect different members of the community. No one objects to taxation for the furtherance of the war, but there has been such a material alteration in these proposals from those that were under our consideration a short while ago , that an explanation of why the disparities are approved of by the Government is called for from the Minister. Under former taxation proposals, an exemption of £156 was allowed, disappearing when the taxable income reached £1,020. It is proposed now that the exemption shall disappear when the taxable income reaches £500. We were told that the new proposals mean,t, in effect, an increase of 25 per cent, in the taxation on incomes, conveying the impression to most honorable senators that the 25 per cent, increase would be general in its application. But, in actual working, it will not have that effect. In some cases incomes will have to pay an increase of at least 100* percent.
112 per cent
Whereas , in the case of those in receipt of very big incomes, the increase will amount to about 25 per cent. That arrangement is manifestly unfair.
- The Minister should be able to give us some examples.

I went on to show how unfairly the tax will operate. Under the former proposals, a man in receipt of a taxable income of £400 a year would pay £ 3 19s. Under these proposals he will pay £7 19s. 7d. Under the proposals of the former Treasurer a person with a taxable income of £500 would pay £6 3s., but under this proposal he would pay £12 13s. 3d.
- More than 100 per cent

Yes . Then a man in receipt of a taxable income of £600 a year would, under the former proposal, pay £9 8s. 9d., and under this scheme £16 18s. Id . ; while a man in receipt of a taxable income of £1,500 a year would pay, under the former scheme, £53 18s. Id . , and under this £67 7s. 7d., the increase in the latter case being not quite 25 per cent. The man in receipt of >a taxable income of £2,000 a year would, under the former proposal, pay £87 10s., and under this £109 7s. 6d.
- Still not quite 25 per cent.

I cannot understand why the Government agreed to such an unfair system of taxation. If there is to be an increase i t should be general in its application, and everybody should pay in proportion to income. If any disparity be made i t should be in the direction of easing the burden on the man with the smaller income.
- If anything, the increases should be graduated.
- Then agree to it.
The system seems to be based on unsound lines, and I would like to get from the Minister an explanation of the reasons for this exceptional increase in taxation on the middle-class incomes.

. - The point raised by Senator Findley touches on the general policy with regard to exemptions. The general exemption is £156 in the case of a person, other than a company, an absentee, or a person without a dependant, and it will be reduced by £5 for every £11 increase in the taxable income over £156, until it disappears when the total taxable income from all sources reaches £500. In the case of a person not being an absentee, and having no dependants, the general exemption will be £100. This will be reduced . by £1 for every £4 by which the taxable income exceeds £100. so that the exemption will disappear when the total taxable income reaches £500. I pointed out when I was referring to this matter at the time, that the notes handed to me showed that the exemption had been altered, and that the average rate of increase was 25 per cent.
But i t is over 100 per cent, in some cases.

I regret that I have not the tables by me, although I endeavoured to get them when Senator Findley made an inquiry upon the point. I presume the honorable senator is fairly well satisfied with his calculations.
- They represent the rates so far as I am able to work them out.
They are approximately correct
- There is no doubt about that.
I might tell the Minister that they are not Mr. Knibbs' figures.

I have some figures indicating the position under the proposed average increase of 25 per cent. These show that a taxable income of £500 would, under the old system, pay £ 6 3s., and under the new, £10 3s. Id. , with 25 per cent, increase, £2 10s. 9d., making a total, £12 13s. 10d., the increase being £6 10s. lOd. A taxable income of £700 would, under the old system, pay £13 5s., under the new £16 8s. Id . , 25 per cent, increase, £ 4 2s., or a total of £20 10s. Id . , the increase in this case being £ 7 5s. Id. A taxable income of £1,000 under the old system would pay £20 17s. 3d., under the new £28 2s. 6di, with 25 per cent, increase, £7 7s., or a total of £35 3s. Id . , the increase being £ 7 5s. lOd.
- The Minister's figures show that the increase on a taxable income of £700 is as great as the increase on the taxable income of £1,000.
Yes. - In the one case i t works out at £7 5s. Id . , and in the other at £7 5s. lOd. The Government are aware, of course, that this represents heavy taxation.
- We are not complaining about the weight of taxation so much as the iniquity of its incidence.
A s a matter of fact, in its operation this new scheme is more scientific than any previous proposal.
No . The richer the man is the lighter the increase.
This is war time, and an increase of taxation is inevitable. The Government adopted the scheme after mature consideration.

. - It will be remembered that when we were discussing the former Income Tax Assessment Bill I asked the Minister in charge if he would give some explanation of the parabolic curve of ' taxation which then expressed the formula for taxing incomes, and the Minister simply assured the Senate that it was a line laid down by Mr. Knibbs. We accepted that assurance, but I did so under protest, and now what do we find ? The Government propose to increase the income tax, but instead of the curve being convex it has taken concave shape so far as certain incomes are concerned. It is now not really a curve at all, but a sinuous line', and, as a matter of fact, the exact increase levied upon individuals in receipt of incomes between £300 and £800 a year comes to practically the same amount in £ s. d. as the extra sum to be exacted from men with incomes of over £1,000 a year, ls this equitable? I do not think that any honorable senator can justify the incidence of this scheme. On a former occasion I deemed it necessary to criticise the formula applied to the assessment of incomes, and now, when an attempt is being made to increase the demands on the people of this country, can it be said that the call is being made in proportion to income, as was the case before this extra taxation became necessary ?
No.

nde r this scheme we are calling on the men in receipt of from £300 to £800 to furnish an extra levy almost exactly the same in amount as the extra call being made on men in receipt of £1,500 a year. Senator Findley has done a great service to Parliament and to the country by exposing the provisions of this Bill, and honorable senators ought to feel indebted to him. When I was speaking on this matter in connexion with the previous Assessment Bill , I said that i t would be necessary for the Government to get out ready reckoners, so that the people would be able to ascertain how much would be levied on their incomes, and now, when we are endeavouring to increase the revenue from income tax, we .find that a largely increased levy is to be made upon those who are in receipt of the smaller incomes. I would sooner let this Bill go altogether, and allow the other House to consider i t at some other time, than to be a party to perpetrating on the middle classes of this community the injustices sought to be imposed by this measure.

. - This is another evidence of the effect of introducing legislation just at a time when honorable senators are anxious to get away to their homes ; and I can see looming in the distance the time when, if the. Government introduce measures like this, the Senate will simply adjourn over the holidays and resume to go on with the business.- Is it fair that the Senate should be asked to consider a measure like this? In the first place, the Bill brought down was just the taxing

speech.para: Bill. The Government have now brought down a complicated measure which one could not thoroughly understand without devoting a day or two of solid work to the task of comparing it with the original Act. We were allowing this Bill to pass almost without any criticism when this question was raised. On the motion for the second reading of the Bill I asked the Minister, by way of interjection, whether he would give us some examples of how this proposed amendment of the Act would work out, and he replied that he would do so later on. Senator Findley had already worked out what would be the extent of the increase of taxation in respect of a number of/ incomes, and he has shown that under this proposal men who are in receipt of the smaller incomes of from £300 to £700 or £800 a year will be called upon to bear a greater share of this increased tax than will these in receipt of larger incomes. I should like to know whether the Government deliberately laid themselves out to do this. Did they merely say, " We want an increase of 25 per cent, in the tax," without taking care to see that the bulk of the increase would not fall upon those in receipt of the smaller incomes ? I believe it would be better either to send this Bill back to another place for further consideration or to allow the whole question to stand over till we meet again. The Bill, even if passed now, would not be put in force before the date on which it is proposed to re-assemble.

talk.start.para: We could strike out this clause now, and that would settle the matter.
Quite so.
- As another place has already adjourned till to-morrow, there is no reason why we should pit all night. The honorable senator should move that progress be reported.
The Minister should do that.

. - I think it would be wise to report progress and allow this question to stand over till to-morrow morning. If I am any judge of the temper of the Committee I think this clause is likely to be struck out, so that the Government will do well to come prepared to-morrow with something to take its place.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

quote.para: That the Senate do now adjourn.

speech.para: I wish to clear up a few arrears of work that have accumulated within the last few days. I have first a statement to make in reference to Senator Gardiner's' remarks concerning a number of officers who have qualified for commissions in Australia, and for whom it has been found impossible to find positions. Senator Gardiner suggested, first of all, that these officers should be sent to the front, and in the alternative that they should be sent to the Old Country, and the British authorities asked to find places for them. The honorable senator is quite justified in the anxiety he has displayed in regard to these men, but there are difficulties in the way of dealing with them satisfactorily. In the first place, the men at the front to-day who are eligible for promotion would naturally feel aggrieved if men coming fresh from Australia were placed over their heads. Then with respect to the second suggestion, we learn that in the camps in Great Britain special schools of instruction have been established for the training of men who have returned from the field of battle, and they are qualifying as commissioned and noncommissioned officers in those schools of instruction. To replace them with men sent fresh from Australia would raise just the same difficulty. It is clear, therefore, that the matter is beset with difficulties which were not apparent at the outset. Senator Millen, I believe, made the same suggestion as did Senator Gardiner.

talk.start.para: I made the suggestion that the Government should communicate with the Imperial Government with a view to asking them to absorb these officers. I merely wished the suggestion considered, because I cannot expect an answer from the honorable senator just now.

The difficulties I have enumerated were mentioned to me by the Defence authorities for the purpose of explanation in the Senate. The suggestion made by Senator Millen will, of course, be attended to. Senator Millen yesterday asked a question with regard to the permanent guard. He asked whether i t was part of the scheme of defence, and whether it would continue longer than the duration of the war. The answer supplied to me is that the object is to provide sentries for factories, munition works, etc, and that the guard is only to exist during the period of the war. The next question I have to deal with is a deferred question by Senator McKissock, . which appears on the business-paper to-day. The honorable senator asked—

quote.para: If, in relation to ChriBtraas leave for soldiers in Australian military camps, he will eliminate travelling time from the leave of soldiers whose homes are distant from the places in which they are encamped, in order that they may be enabled to take full advantage of such leave T

continue.para: The answer supplied is as follows:—

quote.para: Approval has been given for leave to be granted to members of the Australian Imperial Force on Sunday, the 24th, Monday, 25th, Tuesday, 26th, and Wednesday, 27th of December, 1916, and on Sunday, 31st December, 1816, Monday, the 1st, and Tuesday, 2nd January, 1917.

Military Commandants have been authorized to grant leave on Saturday, 23rd December, 1916, to men who desire to go home for Christmas, but who, on account of the distance from home, cannot reach there unless leave is given on 23rd December, 1916.

continue.para: Another postponed question is one asked by Senator Ready. He asked—

item.para: Is the Minister aware that cases are heing brought under the notice of members of the Senate of men who were called up under the recent proclamation for military service being refused reinstatement in their former positions by certain employers
Does the Government intend taking any action to prevent such occurrences ?

continue.para: The reply is-

item.para: Yes.

The Attorney-General's Department has given the opinion that section 134 of the Defence Act does not apply in the case of those called up under Fart IV. of the Act. If this is found to be so, the matter will be specially dealt with by regulation under the War Precautions Act.

continue.para: A question was put by Senator Mullan with respect to the publication in the press of the manifesto issued to the Australian Imperial Force in connexion with the referendum. The answer I have to give to the honorable senator's question is that there is no objection to such manifesto appearing in the press. Senator Needham made an inquiry concerning the proposed Industrial Commission to America. He wished to know the intention of the Government, and whether, if they had arrived at a decision to send the Industrial Commission, an announcement of the personnel of the Commission would soon be made. I have to say that the sending of an Industrial Commission to the United States of America has not yet been considered by the present Government Senator O'Keefe raised a question as to financial standing of coal mining companiess in NBW South Wales. I have a reply from the secretary to the Prime Minister tb the effect that the Government is not in a position at present to supply the information desired by Senator O'Keefe, but i t has communicated with the Premier of New South "Wales in the hope that he will supply the necessary information, as i t is through his Government alone that the information can he obtained. Then there was a further postponed question by Senator Ready, who asked the Assistant Minister—

item.para: Is he aware whether many complaints have been publicly made as to the high rates of steam-ship freights and fares between Tasmania and the mainland, and King Island and Victoria and Tasmania?
Will the Government bring the whole question of these freights and fares before the Inter-State Commission, or the Australian and Tasmanian. Prices Commissioners, for full investigation?

continue.para: The answer is-

item.para: Specific complaints have not been made
These matters are provided for in the War Precautions Prices Begulations, and inquiries will be undertaken.

talk.start.para: - I can give the honorable senator specific complaints if he wants them.
We shall be glad to have them.

. - I regret the answer given by Senator Lynch as to those officers, who, at great inconvenience and expense to themselves, have qualified for commissions. I take the answer as an attempt to reply to the arguments I put forward the other day. I was not, however, putting the case with a view to argument, but simply stating a fact that was- clear to every one, namely, that this represents the tearing up of a "scrap of paper." Here we have capable, willing young men, who are tossed aside simply because there is some present difficulty. I have no desire to prevent the men at the front from getting promotion, but we have here a number of highly-trained, efficient officers, anxious to get to the front, and it is our duty to send them there.
As officers?

As emergency officers. The country, I am sure, would not begrudge the expense, seeing that, in the future, we could have the advantage . of the'services of men who have seen real fighting. The position is so serious that I feel sure the Minister has not really considered it in giving his answer. In Victoria, there are thirty-five young men, fresh from the training school, and yet they are told, at a day's notice, that their services are not required, though we are at war. I am sure that, amongst the Australian officers at the front, there could be found as many who could be well given a spell. Late as the hour is, I could not allow the Minister's reply to pass without again trying to seriously impress upon the Government .the urgency of giving proper consideration to this matter.

. - I thank the Minister for Works for replying to the' question that I addressed to him privately this afternoon in connexion with the proposal of the previous Government to send an Industrial Commission to America. On the 30th November I asked whether the Government had given further consideration to the question, and, if so, when they would be in a position to announce the personnel of the Commission. The reply I received from. Senator Pearce then Was that the matter was " under the consideration of the Government." To-day, however, the Minister for Works tells us that the question has not yet been considered by this Government. With all due deference to the honorable gentleman and his Government, I think it is quite time' that the question was determined yea or nay. During the absence of the Prime Minister in England, Senator Pearce, who was Acting Prime Minister, was at a certain function in Melbourne, presided over by Mr. Brooks,, who suggested that such a Commission should be sent to America.
